846{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/government-fact-finding-mission-shows-846-killed-in-egypt-uprising-1.356885|title=846 killed in Egypt uprising|date=20 April 2011|accessdate=20 April 2011}} (including at least 135 protesters, 12 policemen,{{cite news| url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704740204576273071880564288.html?mod=fox_australian| title=Unrest in Egypt| accessdate=20 April 2011| date=20 April 2011| work=The Wall Street Journal}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-11777943|title=Egypt: Mubarak Sacks Cabinet and Defends Security Role|work=BBC News |date=29 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/jan/26/egypt-protests#block-11|title=Protests in Egypt â As It Happened (Live Blog)|date=26 January 2011|accessdate=26 January 2011|work=The Guardian |location=UK |first1=Haroon|last1=Siddique|first2=Paul|last2=Owen|first3=Jonathan|last3=Haynes|first4=Adam|last4=Gabbatt}} 189 prisoners,{{cite news|title=Amnesty: Egypt far from justice over unrest that killed more than 800|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/05/19/egypt.revolution.report/index.html?hpt=T2|accessdate=19 May 2011|19 May 2011|publisher=CNN|date=11 May 2011}} and one prison chief){{cite news|last=News Service|first=Indo-Asian|title=10 killed as protesters storm Cairo building|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/10-killed-as-protesters-storm-Cairo-building/Article1-656402.aspx|accessdate=30 January 2011|work=Hindustan Times |location=India|date=30 January 2011}}{{cite news|author=Davies, Wyre |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12331520 |title=Egypt Unrest: Protesters Hold Huge Cairo Demonstration |work=BBC News |accessdate=1 February 2011 |date=1 February 2011}}'' :''See: [[#Deaths|Deaths]] section below.''

| casualties_label = | notes = }} {{Politics of Egypt}} The '''2011 Egyptian revolution''' ({{lang-ar|Ø«ÙØ±Ø© 25 ÙÙØ§ÙØ±}} ''thawret 25 yanÄyir'', Revolution of 25 January) took place following a popular uprising that began on Tuesday, 25 January 2011 and is still continuing as of December 2011. The uprising was mainly a campaign of non-violent [[civil resistance]], which featured a series of [[Demonstration (people)|demonstrations]], marches, acts of [[civil disobedience]], and labour strikes. Millions of protesters from a variety of [[socio-economic]] and religious backgrounds demanded the overthrow of the regime of [[Egyptian President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]]. Despite being predominantly peaceful in nature, the revolution was not without violent clashes between security forces and protesters, with at least 846 people killed and 6,000 injured.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/node/385140 |title=Ø´ÙØ­Ø©: ÙÙØ§ØªØ¨ Ø§ÙØµØ­Ø© ÙØ«ÙØª Ø³ÙÙØ· 840 Ø´ÙÙØ¯Ø§Ù Ø®ÙØ§Ù Ø«ÙØ±Ø© 25 ÙÙØ§ÙØ± |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date=16 March 2011 |accessdate=4 April 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14075493 |title=Egypt: Cairo's Tahrir Square fills with protesters |publisher=BBC |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate=11 July 2011}} The uprising took place in [[Cairo]], [[Alexandria]], and in other cities in Egypt, following the [[Tunisian revolution]] that resulted in the overthrow of the long-time Tunisian president. On 11 February, following weeks of determined popular protest and pressure, Mubarak resigned from office. Grievances of Egyptian protesters were focused on legal and political issues{{cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1473531/Q&A--What-s-behind-the-unrest-|title=Q&A: What's Behind the Unrest?|publisher=SBS|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}} including [[police brutality]], [[Emergency law in Egypt|state of emergency]] laws, lack of free elections and [[freedom of speech]], uncontrollable corruption, and economic issues including high unemployment, [[food inflation|food price inflation]], and low [[minimum wage]]s. The primary demands from protest organizers were the end of the [[Hosni Mubarak]] regime and the end of emergency law; freedom, justice, a responsive non-military government, and a say in the management of Egypt's resources.{{Cite news|url=http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2011/01/egyptian-activists-action-plan-translated/70388/|title=Egyptian Activists' Action Plan: Translated|work=[[The Atlantic]]|date=27 January 2011}} Strikes by [[Trade unions in Egypt|labour unions]] added to the pressure on government officials.{{cite web|url=http://www.defenddemocracy.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11792083&Itemid=347 |title=Trade unions: the revolutionary social network at play in Egypt and Tunisia |publisher=Defenddemocracy.org |accessdate=11 February 2011}} During the uprising the capital city of Cairo was described as "a war zone,"{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/global/blog/2011/jan/25/middleeast-tunisia#block-32|title=Protests in Egypt and unrest in Middle East â as it happened|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=26 January 2011|work=The Guardian |location=UK|first1=Haroon|last1=Siddique|first2=Paul|last2=Owen|first3=Adam|last3=Gabbatt}} and the port city of [[Suez]] was the scene of frequent violent clashes. The government imposed a [[curfew]] that protesters defied and that the police and military did not enforce. The presence of Egypt's [[Central Security Forces]] police, loyal to Mubarak, was gradually replaced by largely restrained military troops. In the absence of police, there was [[looting]] by gangs that opposition sources said were instigated by plainclothes police officers. In response, watch groups were organised by civilians to protect neighbourhoods.{{Cite news|last=Fleishman|first=Jeffrey and Edmund Sanders (Los Angeles Times)|title=Unease in Egypt as police replaced by army, neighbors band against looters|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2014078461_egypt30.html|accessdate=1 February 2011|newspaper=The Seattle Times|date=29 January 2011}}{{Cite news|title=Looting spreads in Egyptian cities|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011129175926266521.html|accessdate=1 February 2011|publisher=Al Jazeera English|date=29 January 2011}}{{Cite news|last=Hauslohner|first=Abigail|title=The Army's OK with the Protesters, for now|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2045124,00.html#ixzz1CfroWYuj|accessdate=1 February 2011|newspaper=Time.com|date=29 January 2011}}{{Cite news|title=Mubarak plays last card, the army; Police vanish|url=http://www.worldtribune.com/worldtribune/WTARC/2011/me_egypt0078_01_31.asp|accessdate=1 February 2011|newspaper=World Tribune (online)|date=31 January 2011}}{{Cite news|last=Stirewalt|first=Chris|title=Egypt: From Police State to Military Rule|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/01/31/egypt-police-state-military-rule/|accessdate=1 February 2011|publisher=Fox News|date=31 January 2011}} International response to the protests was initially mixed,{{cite web |url=http://www.eurasiareview.com/world-news/world/regional-reaction-mixed-for-egypt-protests-30012011/ |title=Regional Reaction Mixed For Egypt Protests |publisher=Eurasia Review |accessdate=19 February 2011 }}{{dead link|date=June 2011}} though most called for peaceful actions on both sides and moves toward reform. Most Western governments expressed concern about the situation. Many governments issued travel advisories and made attempts to evacuate their citizens from the country.{{cite web |url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90777/90854/7277514.html |title=Travel warning issued, evacuation to start as protests continue in Egypt |date=31 January 2011 |publisher=English People's Daily Online |accessdate=19 February 2011 }} The Egyptian Revolution, along with Tunisian events, has influenced [[Arab Spring|demonstrations]] in other Arab countries including [[Yemen]], [[Bahrain]], [[Jordan]], [[Syria]] and [[Libya]]. Mubarak dissolved his government and appointed military figure and former head of the [[Egyptian General Intelligence Directorate]] [[Omar Suleiman]] as Vice-President in an attempt to quell dissent. Mubarak asked aviation minister and former chief of Egypt's Air Force, [[Ahmed Shafik]], to form a new government. [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] became a major figure of the opposition, with all major opposition groups supporting his role as a negotiator for some form of transitional unity government.{{Cite news|last1=Shadid|first1=Anthony|last2=Kirkpatrick|first2=David D.|title=Opposition Rallies to ElBaradei as Military Reinforces in Cairo|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/31/world/middleeast/31-egypt.html|accessdate=31 January 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=30 January 2011}} In response to mounting pressure, Mubarak announced he would not seek re-election in September.{{Cite news|author=El Deeb, Sarah; Al-Shalchi, Hadeel|title=Egypt Crowds Unmoved by Mubarak's Vow Not To Run|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=12815050|accessdate=1 February 2011|work=[[Associated Press]] (via ''[[ABC News]]'')|date=1 February 2011}} On 11 February Vice President Omar Suleiman announced that Mubarak would be stepping down as president and turning power over to the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]].{{cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121125158705862.html |title=Hosni Mubarak resigns as president |publisher=Al-Jazeera English |date=11 February 2011 }} On 24 May, Mubarak was ordered to stand trial on charges of [[premeditated murder]] of peaceful protestors and, if convicted, could face the death penalty. The military junta, headed by effective head of state [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]], announced on 13 February that the constitution would be suspended, both houses of parliament dissolved, and that the military would rule for six months until elections could be held. The prior cabinet, including Prime Minister [[Ahmed Shafik]], would continue to serve as a caretaker government until a new one is formed.{{cite news |last=el-Malawani |first=Hania |url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/egypts-military-dismantles-mubarak-regime-20110214-1as8u.html |title=Egypt's military dismantles Mubarak regime |date=13 February 2011 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald }} Shafik resigned on 3 March, a day before major protests to get him to step down were planned; he was replaced by [[Essam Sharaf]], the former transport minister.{{cite web | url=http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypts-prime-minsiter-quits-new-govt-soon-army-2011-03-03T093300Z | title=Egypt's prime minsiter quits, new govt soon-army | publisher=Forexyard.com | accessdate=5 March 2011 }} Although Mubarak resigned, the protests have continued amid concerns about how long the military junta will last in Egypt; some are afraid that the military will rule the country indefinitely.http://www.jadaliyya.com/pages/index/1728/reflections-on-egypt-after-march-19 ==Naming== In Egypt and the wider Arab world, the protests and subsequent changes in the government have generally been referred to as the '''25 January Revolution''' ({{lang|ar|Ø«ÙØ±Ø© 25 ÙÙØ§ÙØ±}} ''Thawrat 25 YanÄyir''), '''Freedom Revolution''' ({{lang|ar|Ø«ÙØ±Ø© Ø­Ø±ÙØ©}} ''Thawrat Horeya''),[http://aglobalrevolution.wordpress.com/2011/02/05/egypt-the-bread-and-freedom-revolution/ Egypt: The Bread and Freedom Revolution | A Global Revolution] or '''Rage Revolution''' ({{lang|ar|Ø«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨}} ''Thawrat al-Ä aá¸ab''), and less frequently,{{cite news|journal=[[Al-Ahram]] Weekly|title=The 25 January Revolution (Special issue)|date=10â16 February 2011|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1034/special.htm|accessdate=15 February 2011}} the '''Revolution of the Youth''' ({{lang|ar|Ø«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙØ´Ø¨Ø§Ø¨}} ''Thawrat al-ShabÄb''), '''[[Nelumbo|Lotus]] Revolution'''{{cite news|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-01-28/world/egypt.press.club_1_saad-eddin-ibrahim-egyptian-american-egyptian-people?_s=PM:WORLD |title=Egyptian-American leaders call for U.S. support of 'Lotus Revolution' â CNN |publisher=CNN |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=21 March 2011}} ({{lang|ar|Ø«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙÙÙØªØ³}}), or '''White Revolution''' ({{lang|ar|Ø§ÙØ«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙØ¨ÙØ¶Ø§Ø¡}} ''al-Thawrah al-bayá¸ÄÊ¾'').{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/NewsDetails.aspx?storyid=299386 |title=Business News Â» Investors See White Revolution In Egypt |publisher=Gulf Daily News |date=13 February 2011 |accessdate=21 March 2011}} ==Background== [[File:Hosni Mubarak ritratto.jpg|thumb|upright|Hosni Mubarak in 2009]] [[Hosni Mubarak]] became head of Egypt's [[Semi-presidential system|semi-presidential]] republic government following the 1981 [[Assassination of Anwar El Sadat|assassination of President Anwar El Sadat]], and continued to serve until 2011. Mubarak's 30-year reign made him the longest serving President in Egypt's history,{{cite web |url=http://documentarystorm.com/politics/a-nation-in-waiting/ |title=Egypt: A Nation in Waiting |accessdate=15 February 2011 }} with his [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party (NDS)]] government maintaining one-party rule under a continuous state of emergency.{{cite news|url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/m/hosni_mubarak/index.html|title=Hosni Mubarak|work=The New York Times |date=8 March 2010|accessdate=25 January 2011|first=Michael|last=Slackman}} Mubarak's government earned the support of the West and a continuation of annual aid from the United States by maintaining policies of suppression towards [[Islamic militants]] and peace with [[Israel]]. Hosni Mubarak was often compared to an Egyptian [[pharaoh]] by the media and by some of his critics due to his authoritarian rule.{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/History-s-crossroads/748326 |title=Historyâs crossroads |work=The Indian Express |location=India |accessdate=10 February 2011}} ===Inheritance of Power=== [[File:Gamal Mubarak.jpg|thumb|upright|Gamal Mubarak in 2006]] {{main|Gamal Mubarak}} Gamal Mubarak, the younger of Mubarak's two sons, began being groomed to be his father's successor as the next president of Egypt around the year 2000.Aziz, Muhammad Abdul and Hussein, Youssef (2002) "The President, the Son, and the Military: Succession in Egypt" ''Arab Studies Journal'' 9/10: pp. 73â88 Gamal started receiving considerable attention in the Egyptian media, as there were no other apparent heirs to the presidency.Bee, Jason (2008) [https://webspace.utexas.edu/jmb334/www/documents/article.ASJ.2008.pdf "The Heir Apparency of Gamal Mubarak"] ''Arab Studies Journal'' pp. 36â56 [[Bashar al-Assad]]'s rise to power in [[Syria]] in June 2000, just hours after [[Hafez al-Assad]]'s death sparked a heated debate in the Egyptian press regarding the prospects for a similar scenario occurring in Cairo.Sobelman, Daniel (2001) [http://www.meforum.org/27/gamal-mubarak-president-of-egypt "Gamal Mubarak, President of Egypt?"] ''Middle East Quarterly'' 8(2): pp. 31â40 In the years after [[Egyptian presidential election, 2005|Mubarak's 2005 reelection]] several political groups (most in Egypt are unofficial) on both the left and the right, announced their sharp opposition to the inheritance of power. They demanded political change and asked for a fair election with more than one candidate. In 2006, with opposition rising, The Daily News Egypt reported on an online campaign initiative called the National Initiative against Power Inheritance which demanded Gamal reduce his power. The campaign stated, "President Mubarak and his son constantly denied even the possibility of [succession]. However, in reality they did the opposite, including amending the constitution to make sure that Gamal will be the only unchallenged candidate."{{cite web | url=http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/egyptians-abroad-speak-out-against-inheritance-of-power.html | title=Egyptians abroad speak out against inheritance of power | date=3 October 2006| accessdate=16 April 2011 | author=Al-A'sar, Marwa}} Over the course of the decade perception grew that Gamal would succeed his father. He wielded increasing power as NDP deputy secretary general, in addition to a post he held heading the party's policy committee. Analysts went so far as describing Mubarak's last decade in power as âthe age of Gamal Mubarak.â With Mubarakâs health declining and the leader refusing to appoint a vice-president, Gamal was considered by some to be Egypt's de-facto president.{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/9988/Egypt/Politics-/How-Gamal-brought-down-the-whole-Mubarak-house.aspx | title=How Gamal brought down the whole Mubarak house | publisher=Ahram Online | date=Friday 15 Apr 2011 | accessdate=16 April 2011 | author=Gamal Essam El-Din}} Both Gamal and Hosni Mubarak continued to deny that an inheritance would take place. There was talk, however, of Gamal being ''elected''; with Hosni Mubarak's presidential term set to expire in 2010 there was speculation Gamal would run as the NDP party's candidate in 2011.{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/20/world/africa/20egypt.html | title=Mubarak's Son Proposes Nuclear Program |work=The New York Times | date=20 September 2006 | accessdate=16 April 2011 | author=Michael Slackman and Mona el-Naggar}} After the JanuaryâFebruary 2011 protest, Gamal Mubarak stated that he would not be running for the presidency in the 2011 elections.{{cite news|last=BBC|title=Egypt unrest: Anti-Mubarak protesters fight back|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12357891|newspaper=British Broadcasting Company|date=3 February 2011}} ===Emergency law=== {{main|Emergency law in Egypt}} An [[Emergency law in Egypt|emergency law]] (Law No. 162 of 1958) was enacted after the 1967 [[Six-Day War]]. It was suspended for 18 months in the early 1980s{{cite web |url=http://www.emerglobal.com/lex/law-1958-162 |title=Law 1958/162 (Emergency Law) |work={{ar}} at [http://www.emerglobal.com/lex EMERglobal Lex] January 2011, part of the [[Edinburgh Middle East Report]] |accessdate=2 April 2010 }} and has otherwise continuously been in effect since President Sadat's 1981 assassination.{{cite web|last=Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights|title=Egypt and The Impact of 27 years of Emergency on Human Rights|url=http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110129202417/http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archivedate=29 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=28 May 2008}} Under the law, police powers are extended, [[Constitution of Egypt|constitutional rights]] suspended, censorship is legalised,{{cite web|url=http://conconflicts.ssrc.org/mideast/shehata/|title=Egypt After 9/11: Perceptions of the United States|date=26 March 2004|accessdate=30 January 2011|last=Shehata|first=Samer|work=Contemporary Conflicts}} and the government may imprison individuals indefinitely and without reason. The law sharply limits any non-governmental political activity, including [[Demonstration (people)|street demonstrations]], non-approved political organizations, and unregistered financial donations. The Mubarak government has cited the threat of terrorism in order to extend the emergency law, claiming that opposition groups like the [[Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt|Muslim Brotherhood]] could come into power in Egypt if the current government did not forgo [[parliamentary elections]] and suppress the group through actions allowed under emergency law.{{Cite book|last= Caraley|first= Demetrios|title= American Hegemony: Preventive War, Iraq, and Imposing Democracy|publisher=[[Academy of Political Science]]|year= 2004|month= April|isbn= 1-8848-5304-8}} This has led to the imprisonment of activists without trials,{{cite web|author=Choney, Suzanne|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41285248/ns/technology_and_science-tech_and_gadgets/|title=Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[MSNBC]]}} illegal undocumented hidden detention facilities,{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/10/30/061030ta_talk_mayer|title=The C.I.A.'s Travel Agent|date=30 October 2006|accessdate=28 January 2011|work=The New Yorker |author=Mayer, Jane}} and rejecting university, mosque, and newspaper staff members based on their political inclination.{{cite news|author=Shenker, Jack|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/nov/22/egypt-elections-muslim-brotherhood-ndp|title=Egyptian Elections: Independents Fight for Hearts and Minds in 'Fixed Ballot'|work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=22 November 2010|accessdate=28 January 2011}} A [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010|parliamentary election]] in December 2010 was preceded by a media crackdown, arrests, candidate bans (particularly of the Muslim Brotherhood), and allegations of fraud involving the near-unanimous victory by the ruling party in parliament. Human rights organizations estimate that in 2010 between 5,000 and 10,000 people were in long-term detention without charge or trial.{{cite web|author=[[Press release]]|publisher=[[Amnesty International]]|title=Egypt: Keep Promise to Free Detainees by End of June: Joint Statement|url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/MDE12/027/2010/en|date=29 June 2010|accessdate=4 February 2011}}{{cite web|author=Holder, R. Clemente|url=http://www.washington-report.org/backissues/0794/9407060.htm|title=Egyptian Lawyer's Death Triggers Cairo Protests|work=[[Washington Report on Middle East Affairs]]|date=July/August 1994|accessdate=31 January 2011}} ===Police brutality=== {{see|Law enforcement in Egypt}} According to a report from the U.S. Embassy in Egypt, police brutality has been common and widespread in Egypt.{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/28/egypt-police-brutality-torture-wikileaks|title=US reported 'routine' police brutality in Egypt, WikiLeaks cables show|last=Harding|first=Luke|date=Friday 28 January 2011 15.23 GMT|work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=20 April 2011}} In the last five years, the Mubarak regime has denied the existence of torture or abuse carried out by the police. However, many claims by domestic and international groups provide evidence through cellphone videos or first-hand accounts of hundreds of cases of police abuse.{{cite news|last=U.S. Embassy in Cairo|title=US embassy cables: Police brutality in Egypt|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/us-embassy-cables-documents/187359|newspaper=The Guardian|date=28 January 2011|location=London}} According to the 2009 Human Rights Report by the U.S. State Department, "Domestic and international human rights groups reported that the Ministry of Interior (MOI) State Security Investigative Service (SSIS), police, and other government entities continued to employ torture to extract information or force confessions. The Egyptian Organization for Human Rights documented 30 cases of torture during the year 2009. In numerous trials defendants alleged that police tortured them during questioning. During the year activists and observers circulated some amateur cellphone videos documenting the alleged abuse of citizens by security officials. For example, on 8 February, a blogger posted a video of two police officers, identified by their first names and last initials, sodomizing a bound naked man named Ahmed Abdel Fattah Ali with a bottle. On 12 August, the same blogger posted two videos of alleged police torture of a man in a Port Said police station by the head of investigations, Mohammed Abu Ghazala. There was no indication that the government investigated either case."{{cite web|last=U.S. Department of State|title=2009 Human Rights Report: Egypt|url=http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/nea/136067.htm#|accessdate=11 March 2010}} The deployment of plainclothes forces paid by Mubarak's ruling party, Baltageya, ({{lang-ar|Ø¨ÙØ·Ø¬ÙØ©}}), has been a hallmark of the Mubarak government.{{Cite news|author=Kirkpatrick, David; Fahim, Kareem|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Gunfire Rings Out as Protesters Clash|work=The New York Times |date=3 February 2011| accessdate=3 February 2011}} The [[Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights]] has documented 567 cases of torture, including 167 deaths, by police that occurred between 1993 and 2007.{{Cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6943704.stm|title=Egyptian Police Sued for Boy's Death|work=BBC News |date=13 August 2007|accessdate=4 February 2011}} Excessive force was often used by law enforcement agencies. The police forces constantly squelched democratic uprisings with brutal force and corrupt tactics.{{cite news|url=http://www.inwent.org/ez/articles/192821/index.en.shtml |title=Arab countriesâ secret police forces have a reputation for torture and arbitrary arrests |publisher=D+C 2011/03 â International Journal |month=March |year=2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}} On 6 June 2010 [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Mohamed Saeed died under disputed circumstances]] in the [[Sidi Gaber]] area of [[Alexandria]]. Multiple witnesses testified that Saeed was beaten to death by the police.{{Cite news|author=Khalil, Ashraf|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/51909|title=Anger in Alexandria: 'We're Afraid of Our Own Government'|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 June 2010|accessdate=4 February 2011}}{{Cite news|title=Two Witnesses Affirm Alexandria Victim Beaten by Police|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/50228|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=19 June 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011}} A Facebook page called "We are all Khaled Said" helped bring nationwide attention to the case.{{cite news|last=Levinson |first=Charles |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703445904576118502819408990.html |title=How Cairo, U.S. Were Blindsided by Revolution |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=2 February 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}} [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], led a rally in 2010 in Alexandria against alleged abuses by the police and visited Saeed's family to offer condolences.{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201062642955204618.html|title=ElBaradei Leads Anti-Torture Rally|publisher=Al Jazeera English|date=26 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}} During the January â February 2011 protests, police brutality was high in response to the protests. Jack Shenker, a reporter for ''[[The Guardian]]'', was arrested during the mass protests in Cairo on 26 January 2011. He witnessed fellow Egyptian protesters being tortured, assaulted, and taken to undisclosed locations by police officers. Shenker and other detainees were released after one of his fellow detainees' well-known father, [[Ayman Nour]], covertly intervened.{{cite news|last=Shenker|first=Jack|title=Bloody and Bruised: The Journalist Caught in Egypt Unrest|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/27/egypt-riot-security-force-action|newspaper=The Guardian|date=27 January 2011|location=London}}{{cite news|last=BBC|title=Profile: Ayman Nour|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/4558054.stm|newspaper=British Broadcasting Company|date=24 December 2005}}{{cite news|title=Profile of Ayman Nour|url=http://egyptelections.carnegieendowment.org/2010/09/09/profile-of-ayman-nour|newspaper=Carnegie Endowment for International Peace|date=9 September 2009}} ===Corruption in government elections=== Accusations of corruption, coercion to not vote, and manipulation of the election results have occurred during many of the elections over the past 30 years.{{cite news|last=U.S. Department of State, Embassy of Egypt|title=Subject: Struggling to Address Police Brutality|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/us-embassy-cables-documents/187359|location=London |work=The Guardian |date=28 January 2011}} Until 2005, Mubarak was the only candidate to run for the presidency, on a yes/no vote.{{cite news|last=Democracy Reporting International and Egyptian Organization for Human Rights|title=Final Report: Assessment of the Electoral Framework in the Arab Republic of Egypt|url=http://www.democracy-reporting.org/downloads/reports/dri_egypt.pdf|year=2007}} Mubarak has won five consecutive presidential elections with a sweeping majority. Opposition groups and international election monitoring agencies have accused the elections of being rigged. These agencies have not been allowed to monitor the elections. The only opposing presidential candidate in recent Egyptian history, [[Ayman Nour]], was imprisoned before the 2005 elections.{{cite news|last=Sharp|first=Jeremy|title=Egypt: Background and U.S. Relations|url=http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/mideast/RL33003.pdf|newspaper=Congressional Research Service|year=2009}} According to a UN survey, voter turnout is extremely low (around 25%) because of the lack of trust in the corrupt representational system.{{cite news|last=Democracy Reporting International and Egyptian Organization for Human Rights|title=Final Report: Assessment of the Electoral Framework in the Arab Republic of Egypt|url=http://www.democracy-reporting.org/downloads/reports/dri_egypt.pdf|newspaper=Congressional Research Service|year=2007}} ===Restrictions on free speech and press=== Even though the Egyptian constitution provides for the universal freedom of speech (Egypt Constitution, Article 47 â 49),{{cite news|title=The Constitution of the Arab Republic of Egypt|url=http://www.egypt.gov.eg/english/laws/constitution/default.aspx|accessdate=7 April 2011|year=1971}} the government has frequently sanctioned home raids, torture, arrests, and fining of bloggers and reporters that criticize the government in any way. Under the current state of emergency laws, the government can censor anything if it is considered a threat to âpublic safety and national securityâ. If any reporter or blogger violates this law by criticizing the government, they could be legally penalized with a fine of 20,000 pounds ($3,650) and up to five years in prison. The Moltaqa Forum for Development and Human Rights Dialogue reported that between January and March 2009, 57 journalists from 13 newspapers faced legal penalties for their governmental critiques. The Egyptian government owns stock in the three largest daily newspapers. The government controls the licensing and distribution of all papers in Egypt.{{cite news|last=U.S. Department of State, Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor|title=Human Rights Report: Egypt|url=http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/nea/136067.htm#|date=11 March 2010}} The Egyptian government shut down the Internet to most of Egypt during the recent protests in order to limit communication between protest groups.{{cite news|last=Robertson|first=Jordan|title=The day part of the Internet died: Egypt goes dark|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/jan/28/day-part-internet-died-egypt-goes-dark/|newspaper=The Washington Times|date=28 January 2011}} ===Demographic and economic challenges=== ; Unemployment and reliance on subsidized goods {{see|Demographics of Egypt|Demographic trap|Youth bulge}} [[File:Egypt population pyramid 2005.svg|thumb|Population pyramid in 2005. Many of those 30 and younger are educated citizens who are experiencing difficulty finding work.]] The population of Egypt grew from 30,083,419 in 1966The British Oxford Economic Atlas of the World, 4th edition. ISBN 0198941072 to roughly 79,000,000 by 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.msrintranet.capmas.gov.eg/pls/fdl/tst12e?action=&lname=|title=Central Agency for Population Mobilisation and Statistics â Population Clock (July 2008)|publisher=Msrintranet.capmas.gov.eg|accessdate=25 August 2010}} The vast majority of Egyptians live in the limited spaces near the banks of the [[Nile]] River, in an area of about {{convert|40000|km2|sp=us}}, where the only [[arable land]] is found. In late 2010 around 40% of Egypt's population of just under 80 million lived on the fiscal income equivalent of roughly US$2 per day, with a large part of the population relying on subsidized goods. According to the [[Peterson Institute for International Economics]] and other proponents of demographic structural approach ([[cliodynamics]]), a basic problem in Egypt is unemployment driven by a demographic [[youth bulge]]: with the number of new people entering the job force at about 4% a year, unemployment in Egypt is almost 10 times as high for [[college graduate]]s as it is for people who have gone through elementary school, particularly educated urban youthâthe same people who were out in the streets during the revolution.[[Korotayev|Korotayev A.]], Zinkina J. [http://cliodynamics.ru/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=276&Itemid=70 Egyptian Revolution: A Demographic Structural Analysis. ''Entelequia. Revista Interdisciplinar'' 13 (2011): 139â169.]{{cite web|url=http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2011/02/01/pm-the-long-term-challenges-egypt-must-overcome/|title=The long-term economic challenges Egypt must overcome|work=[[Marketplace (radio program)|Marketplace]]|date=1 February 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}} ; Poor living conditions and economic conditions {{see|Economy of Egypt}} [[File:Flickr - Daveness 98 - Cityscape in Cairo.jpg|thumb|A poor neighbourhood in Cairo]] Egypt's economy was highly centralised during the tenure of President [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] but opened up considerably under President Anwar Sadat and Mubarak. From 2004 to 2008 the Mubarak-led government aggressively pursued economic reforms to attract foreign investment and facilitate GDP growth, but postponed further economic reforms because of global economic turmoil. The international [[economic downturn]] slowed Egypt's GDP growth to 4.5% in 2009. In 2010 analysts said the government of Prime Minister [[Ahmed Nazif]] would need to restart economic reforms to attract foreign investment, boost growth, and improve economic conditions. Despite high levels of national economic growth over the past few years, living conditions for the average Egyptian remained poor,{{cite web|url=http://www.theodora.com/wfbcurrent/egypt/egypt_economy.html|title=Egypt Economy 2011|author=Source: [[CIA World Factbook]] and other sources |accessdate=3 March 2011}} though better than many other countries in Africa. ===Corruption among government officials=== {{see|Crime in Egypt}} Political corruption in Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]] rose dramatically due to the increased level of control over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency.{{Cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: Liberalism, Islam, and Democracy in the Arab World|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=2008|month=November|isbn= 0-6911-3665-3}} The rise to power of powerful businessmen in the NDP, in the government, and in the People's Assembly led to massive waves of anger during the years of Prime Ministers Ahmed Nazif's government. An example is [[Ahmed Ezz]]'s [[Monopoly|monopolising]] the steel industry in Egypt by holding more than 60% of the market share.{{Cite book|title=The Report: Egypt 2007|publisher=[[Oxford Business Group]]|year=2007|month=January|isbn= 1-9023-3957-6}} Aladdin Elaasar, an Egyptian biographer and an American professor, estimates that the Mubarak family is worth from $50 to $70 billion.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/aladdin-elaasar/egyptians-rise-against-th_b_815520.html |title=Egyptians Rise Against Their Pharoah |work=Huffington Post |location=USA |last=Elaasar |first=Aladdin |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/egypt-mubarak-family-accumulated-wealth-days-military/story?id=12821073&page=2|title=Egypt's Mubarak Likely to Retain Vast Wealth|work=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=5 February 2011}} The wealth of [[Ahmed Ezz]], the former NDP Organisation Secretary, is estimated to be 18 billion [[Egyptian pound]]s;{{cite web|url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90033584?Obama%20optimistic%20about%20Egypt%20as%20negotiators%20make%20concessions|title=Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions|publisher=AHN|accessdate=9 February 2011}} the wealth of former Housing Minister Ahmed al-Maghraby is estimated to be more than 11 billion Egyptian pounds; the wealth of former Minister of Tourism [[Zuhair Garrana]] is estimated to be 13 billion Egyptian pounds; the wealth of former Minister of Trade and Industry, Rashid Mohamed Rashid, is estimated to be 12 billion Egyptian pounds; and the wealth of former Interior Minister Habib al-Adly is estimated to be 8 billion Egyptian pounds. The perception among Egyptians was that the only people to benefit from the nation's wealth were businessmen with ties to the National Democratic Party; "wealth fuels political power and political power buys wealth."{{cite web|author=Inside Story |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/programmes/insidestory/2011/02/201128111236245847.html |title=How did Egypt become so corrupt? â Inside Story |publisher=Al Jazeera English |accessdate=9 February 2011}} During the [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010]], opposition groups complained of harassment and fraud perpetrated by the government. Opposition and civil society activists have called for changes to [[National Association for Change#Platform|a number of legal]] and [[National Association for Change#Goals|constitutional provisions which affect elections]].{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} In 2010 [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] (CPI) report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1, based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts (with 10 being clean and 0 being totally corrupt).{{cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|title=CPI 2010 table|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=26 October 2010}} ==Lead-up to the protests== To prepare for a possible overthrow of Mubarak, opposition groups studied the work of [[Gene Sharp]] on non-violent revolution and worked with leaders of [[Otpor!]], the student-led [[Serbia]]n uprising of [[Overthrow of Slobodan MiloÅ¡eviÄ|2000]]. Copies of Sharp's list of 198 non-violent "weapons", translated into Arabic and not always attributed to him, were circulated in [[Tahrir Square]] during its occupation.{{cite news | first = David D. | last = Kirkpatrick | coauthors = David E. Sanger | title = A Tunisian-Egyptian link that shook Arab history | date=13 February 2011 | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/14/world/middleeast/14egypt-tunisia-protests.html | work=The New York Times | accessdate=27 February 2011 }}{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12522848 |title=Gene Sharp: Author of the nonviolent revolution rulebook |publisher=BBC News |date=21 February 2011 }} ===Tunisian Revolution=== {{main|Tunisian Revolution}} {{see|Arab Spring}} After the ousting of Tunisian president [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]] due to mass protests, many analysts, including former [[European Commission President]] [[Romano Prodi]], saw Egypt as the next country where such a revolution might occur.{{cite news|last=Remondini|first=Chiara|title=Prodi Says Egypt to Be Monitored After Tunisia, Messaggero Says|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-16/prodi-says-egypt-to-be-monitored-after-tunisia-messaggero-says.html|accessdate=12 February 2011|newspaper=Bloomberg L.P.|date=16 January 2011}} ''[[The Washington Post]]'' commented, "The Jasmine Revolution [...] should serve as a stark warning to Arab leaders â beginning with Egypt's 83-year-old Hosni Mubarak â that their refusal to allow more economic and political opportunity is dangerous and untenable."{{cite news|title=Tunisia's revolution should be a wake-up call to Mideast autocrats|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/15/AR2011011503141.html|accessdate=11 February 2011|newspaper=Washington Post|date=15 January 2011}} Others held the opinion that Egypt was not ready for revolution, citing little aspiration of the Egyptian people, low educational levels, and a strong government with the support of the military.{{cite news|last=Hauslohner|first=Abigail|title=After Tunisia: Why Egypt Isn't Ready to Have Its Own Revolution|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2043497,00.html|accessdate=12 February 2011|newspaper=Time|date=20 January 2011}} The [[BBC]] said, "The simple fact is that most Egyptians do not see any way that they can change their country or their lives through political action, be it voting, activism, or going out on the streets to demonstrate."{{cite news|last=Leyne|first=Jon|title=No sign Egypt will take the Tunisian road|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12202937|accessdate=11 February 2011|newspaper=BBC |date=17 January 2011}} ===Self-immolation=== [[File:The lion of Egyptian revolution (Qasr al-Nil Bridge)-edit2.jpg|thumb|A protester holds an Egyptian flag during the protests that started on 25 January 2011 in Egypt]] Following the self-immolation of [[Mohamed Bouazizi]] in Tunisia on 17 December, a man set himself ablaze on 17 January in front of the Tunisian parliament;{{cite news|last=Zayed|first=Dina|title=Egyptians set themselves ablaze after Tunisia unrest|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/18/us-tunisia-egypt-immolation-idUSTRE70H3L720110118|accessdate=12 February 2011|agency=Reuters |date=16 January 2011}} about five more attempts of self-immolation followed. ===National Police Day protests=== Opposition groups planned a day of revolt for 25 January, coinciding with the [[National Police Day (Egypt)|National Police Day]]. The purpose was to protest against abuses by the police in front of the [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]].{{cite news|title=Muslim Brotherhood To Participate in 25 January Protest|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/303296|accessdate=8 April 2011|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=23 January 2011}} These demands expanded to include the resignation of the Minister of Interior, an end to State corruption, the end of [[Emergency law in Egypt|Egyptian emergency law]], and [[term limit]]s for the president. Many political movements, opposition parties, and public figures supported the day of revolt, including [[Youth for Justice and Freedom]], [[Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution]], the [[Popular Democratic Movement for Change]] and the [[National Association for Change]]. The [[6 April Youth Movement]] was a major supporter of the protest and distributed 20,000 leaflets saying "I will protest on 25 January to get my rights". The [[Ghad party|Ghad]], [[Dignity Party (Egypt)|Karama]], [[Wafd party|Wafd]] and [[Democratic Front Party|Democratic Front]] supported the protests. The Muslim Brotherhood, Egypt's largest opposition group, confirmed on 23 January that it would participate.{{cite news|title=Egypt Muslim Brotherhood to participate in 25 January protest |url=http://news.egypt.com/en/2011012313371/news/-egypt-news/egypt-muslim-brotherhood-to-participate-in-25-january-protest.html |accessdate=25 March 2011 |work=Egypt News |date=23 January 2011}} Public figures including novelist [[Alaa Al Aswany]], writer [[Belal Fadl]], and actors [[Amr Waked]] and [[Khaled Aboul Naga]] announced they would participate. However, the [[left-wing politics|leftist]] [[National Progressive Unionist Party]] (the Tagammu) stated it would not participate. The Coptic Church urged Christians not to participate in the protests.{{cite news|last=Afify|first=Heba|title=Activists Hope 25 January Protest Will Be Start of 'Something Big'|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/activists-25-january-protest-be-start-something-big|accessdate=14 March 2011|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=24 January 2011}} Twenty-six-year-old [[Asmaa Mahfouz]] was instrumentalMekay, Emad (11 February 2011). [http://ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=54439 "Arab Women Lead the Charge"]. ''[[Inter Press Service]]''. Retrieved 14 March 2011. in sparking the protests.{{cite news |author=[[Transcript (law)|Transcript]]| title = Women Play Vital Role in Egypt's Uprising | url = http://www.npr.org/2011/02/04/133497422/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising | date=4 February 2011 |work=[[Tell Me More]] (via [[NPR]]) | accessdate=14 March 2011}} In a video blog posted two weeks before National Police Day,{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]| title = Revolutionary Blogger Asma Threatened â Activist Got Calls from NDP Party Members Ordering Her Not To Leave Home or Get Killed | date=5 February 2011 | url = http://gulfnews.com/news/region/egypt/revolutionary-blogger-asma-threatened-1.757171 | work=[[Gulf News]] | accessdate=14 March 2011}} she urged the Egyptian people to join her on 25 January in Tahrir Square to bring down Mubarak's regime.[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02iht-letter02.html?_r=1]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Mahfouz's use of [[video blogging]] and [[social media]] went [[Viral video|viral]][[Xeni Jardin|Jardin, Xeni]] (2 February 2011). [http://boingboing.net/2011/02/02/egypt-the-viral-vlog.html Egypt: The Viral Vlog of Asmaa Mahfouz That Helped Spark an Uprising"]. ''[[Boing Boing]]''. Retrieved 14 March 2011. and urged people not to be afraid.[[Staff writer]] (5 February 2011). [http://www.thecanadiancharger.com/page.php?id=5&a=774 "Asmaaa Mahfouz, a Woman Behind Egypt's Pro-Democracy Revolution"]. ''[[The Canadian Charger]]''. Retrieved 14 March 2011. The Facebook group set up for the event attracted 80,000 attendees. {{-}} ==Protests== ===Timeline=== {{refimprove section|date=April 2011}} {{main|Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution}} [[File:Al Jazeera -Footage Of Egyptian protests 2 - 01292011.ogg|thumb|[[Al Jazeera]] footage of Egyptian protests]] [[File:Day of Anger marchers in street.jpg|thumb|The "Day of Revolt" on 25 January]] [[File:Tahrir Square during Friday of Departure.png|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people protest in [[Tahrir Square]] on 4 February 2011]] [[File:Tahrir Square on February 8 2011.png|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people protest in [[Tahrir Square]] on 8 February 2011]] [[File:Tahrir Square - February 9, 2011.png|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people protest in [[Tahrir Square]] on 9 February 2011]] [[File:Tahrir Square on February11.png|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people celebrate in Tahrir Square when Hosni Mubarak's resignation is announced on 11 February 2011]] [[File:Tahrir Square on April 1 2011.jpg|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 1 April 2011]] [[File:Tahrir Square April 8 2011.png|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 8 April 2011]] [[File:Tahrir Square on May 27 2011.jpg|thumb|Tens of thousands of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 27 May 2011]] '''25 January 2011''': The '''"Day of Revolt"''': Protests erupted throughout Egypt, with tens of thousands of protesters gathered in Cairo and thousands more in cities throughout Egypt. The protests targeted President Hosni Mubarak's government, and mostly adhered to non-violence. There were some reports of civilian and police casualties. '''26 January 2011''': '''"Shutting down The Internet and Mobile Services"''': After several Facebook groups were created and tweets (from Twitter) called for mass demonstrations, the Egyptian government shut down internet access for most of the country.{{cite web|last=Cowie |first=James |url=http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/01/egypt-leaves-the-internet.shtml |title=Egypt Leaves the Internet |publisher=Renesys.com |accessdate=21 March 2011}} This was done to cripple one of the protesters' main organizational tools and to impede the flow of news and people. '''28 January 2011''': The '''"Friday of Anger"''' protests began. Hundreds of thousands demonstrated in Cairo and other Egyptian cities after Friday prayers. Opposition leader Mohamed ElBaradei arrived in Cairo. There were reports of looting. Prisons were opened and burned down, allegedly on orders from then-Minister of the Interior Habib El Adly. Prison inmates escaped en masse, in what was believed to be an attempt to terrorise protesters. Police forces were withdrawn from the streets, and the military was deployed. International fears of violence grew, but no major casualties were reported. President Hosni Mubarak made his first address to the nation and pledged to form a new government. Later that night clashes broke out in Tahrir Square between revolutionaries and pro-Mubarak demonstrators, leading to the injury of several and the death of some. '''29 January 2011''': The military presence in Cairo increased. A curfew was declared, but was widely ignored as the flow of defiant protesters to Tahrir Square continued throughout the night. The military reportedly refused to follow orders to fire live ammunition, and exercised restraint overall. There were no reports of major casualties. '''1 February 2011''': Mubarak made another televised address and offered several concessions. He pledged to not run for another term in the elections planned for September, and pledged political reforms. He stated he would stay in office to oversee a peaceful transition. Small but violent clashes began that night between pro-Mubarak and anti-Mubarak groups. '''2 February 2011''': '''"Battle of the Camel"'''. Violence escalated as waves of Mubarak supporters met anti-government protesters, and some Mubarak supporters rode on camels and horses into Tahrir Square, reportedly wielding swords and sticks. President Mubarak reiterated his refusal to step down in interviews with several news agencies. Incidents of violence toward journalists and reporters escalated amid speculation that the violence was being encouraged by Mubarak as a way to bring the protests to an end. '''6 February 2011''': A multifaith Sunday Mass is held with [[Copts|Egyptian Christians]] and [[Islam in Egypt|Egyptian Muslims]] in Tahrir Square. Negotiations involving Egyptian Vice President [[Omar Suleiman]] and representatives of the opposition commenced amid continuing protests throughout the nation. The Egyptian army assumed greater security responsibilities, maintaining order and guarding The [[Egyptian Museum|Egyptian Museum of Antiquity]]. Suleiman offered reforms, while others of Mubarak's regime accused foreign nations, including the US, of interfering in Egyptâs affairs. '''10 February 2011''': Mubarak formally addressed Egypt amid speculation of a military coup, but rather than resigning (as was widely expected), he simply stated he would delegate some of his powers to Vice President Suleiman, while continuing as Egypt's head of state. Reactions to Mubarak's statement were marked by anger, frustration and disappointment, and throughout various cities there was an escalation of the number and intensity of demonstrations. '''11 February 2011''': The '''"Friday of Departure"''': Massive protests continued in many cities as Egyptians refused the concessions announced by Mubarak. Finally, at 6:00 pm local time, Suleiman announced Mubarak's resignation, entrusting the Supreme Council of Egyptian Armed Forces with the leadership of the country. Nationwide celebrations immediately followed. '''13 February 2011''': The Supreme Council dissolved Egyptâs parliament and suspended the Constitution in response to demands by demonstrators. The council declared that it would hold power for six months, or until elections could be held. Calls were made for the council to provide more details and specific timetables and deadlines. Major protests subsided but did not end. In a gesture to a new beginning, protesters cleaned up and renovated Tahrir Square, the epicenter of the demonstrations, although many pledged they would continue protests until all the demands had been met. '''17 February 2011''': The army stated it would not field a candidate in the upcoming presidential elections.{{cite web|url=http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypt-army-says-wont-field-presidential-candidate-2011-02-17T144839Z |title=Egypt army says won't field presidential candidate |publisher=Forexyard.com |accessdate=20 February 2011}} Four important figures of the former regime were detained on that day: former interior minister [[Habib el-Adly]], former minister of housing [[Ahmed Maghrabi]] former tourism minister [[Zuheir Garana]], and steel tycoon [[Ahmed Ezz]].{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12500968 |title=BBC News â Egypt after Mubarak: Three ex-ministers arrested |publisher=BBC |date=15 February 2011 |accessdate=20 February 2011}} '''2 March 2011''': The [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|constitutional referendum]] was tentatively scheduled for 19 March 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d67e07da-4420-11e0-931d-00144feab49a.html#axzz1FTmeSur8 |title=Egypt sets constitutional referendum date |work=Financial Times |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}} '''3 March 2011''': A day before large protests against him were planned, [[Ahmed Shafik]] stepped down as Prime Minister and was replaced by [[Essam Sharaf]].{{cite web|url=http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypts-prime-minsiter-quits-new-govt-soon-army-2011-03-03T093300Z |title=Egypt's prime minsiter quits, new govt soon-army |publisher=Forexyard.com |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}} '''5 March 2011''': Several [[State Security Intelligence]] (SSI) buildings were raided across Egypt by protesters, including the headquarters for [[Alexandria Governorate]] and the main national headquarters in [[Nasr City]], Cairo. Protesters stated they raided the buildings to secure documents they believed to show various crimes committed by the SSI against the people of Egypt during Mubarak's rule.{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201134228359128.html | title=Egypt security building stormed | publisher=Al Jazeera English | date=5 March 2011 | accessdate=7 March 2011 }}{{cite news | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12674714 | title=Egyptians demand secret police give up torture secrets | author=Leithead, Alastair | publisher=BBC [[BBC News|News]] | date=8 March 2011 | accessdate=8 March 2011 }} '''6 March 2011''': From the Nasr City headquarters, protesters acquired evidence of [[mass surveillance]] and vote rigging, and noted rooms full of videotapes, piles of shredded and burned documents, and cells where activists recounted their experiences of detention and torture.{{cite news | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/03/2011368410372200.html | title = A first step towards prosecutions? | first = Gregg | last = Carlstrom | date=6 Mar 2011 | publisher=Al Jazeera }} '''19 March 2011''': The constitutional referendum was held and passed by 77.27%.{{cite web |url= http://referendum.eg/84-slideshow/158-2011-03-20-19-09-58.html |title= Ø§ÙØ£Ø±ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙÙØ¹ÙÙØ© ÙÙØªØµÙÙØª |publisher=Ø§ÙÙØ¬ÙØ© Ø§ÙÙØ¶Ø§Ø¦ÙØ© Ø§ÙØ¹ÙÙØ§ ÙÙØ¥Ø´Ø±Ø§Ù Ø¹ÙÙ Ø§Ø³ØªÙØªØ§Ø¡ ØªØ¹Ø¯ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± Ø§ÙÙØµØ±Ù |language=[[Arabic]] |accessdate=20 March 2011}} '''22 March 2011''': Parts of the Interior Ministry building catch fire during police demonstrations outside.{{cite news | url = http://www.globaltoronto.com/Fire+sweeps+Egypt+Interior+Ministry+building+police+protest+outside+demand+higher/4484415/story.html | date=22 Mar 2011 | publisher=Global Tornoto }} '''23 March 2011''': The [[Cabinet of Egypt|Egyptian Cabinet]] orders a law criminalising protests and strikes that hampers work at private or public establishments. Under the new law, anyone organising or calling for such protests will be sentenced to jail and/or a fine of LE500,000 (~100,000 USD).{{cite news | url = http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/371465 | date=23 Mar 2011 | publisher=Al Masri Al Youm }} '''1 April 2011''': The '''"Save the Revolution"''' day: Approximately four thousand demonstrators filled Tahrir Square for the largest protest in weeks, demanding that the ruling military council move faster to dismantle lingering aspects of the old regime.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/02/world/middleeast/02egypt.html?_r=1 |title=Protesters Scold Egyptâs Military Council |publisher=Neil MacFarquhar |date=1 April 2011 |accessdate=2 April 2011}} Protestors demanded trial for [[Hosni Mubarak]], [[Gamal Mubarak]], [[Ahmad Fathi Sorour]], [[Safwat El-Sherif]] and [[Zakaria Azmi]] as well. '''8 April 2011''': The '''"Friday of Cleaning"''': Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators again filled Tahrir Square, criticizing the ruling Supreme Council of the Armed Forces for not following through on revolutionary demands. They demanded the resignation of remaining regime figures and the removal of Egyptâs public prosecutor due to the slow pace of investigations of corrupt former officials.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/391552 |title=Tens of thousands in Tahrir as some threaten to extend protests | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |accessdate=9 April 2011}} '''27 May 2011''': The '''"Second Friday of Anger"''' (a.k.a '''"Second Revolution of Anger"''' or '''"The Second Revolution"'''): Tens of thousands of demonstrators filled Tahrir Square in Egypt's capital [[Cairo]],NRC Handelsblad (Dutch), 28 May 2011. besides{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} perhaps demonstrators in each of Alexandria, Suez, Ismailia, Gharbeya and other areas; in the largest demonstrations since ousting Mubarak's Regime. Protestors demanded No Military Trials for Civilians, the Egyptian Constitution to be made before the Parliament Elections and for all the old regime gang and those who killed protestors in January and February to be put on fair Trial. '''1 July 2011''': The '''"Friday of Retribution"'''; Hundreds of thousands of protesters gathered in Suez, Alexandria and Tahrir Square in Cairo, to voice frustration with the ruling Supreme Council of the Armed Forces for what they called the slow pace of change five months after the revolution, some also feared that the military is to rule Egypt indefinitely.{{cite web|url=http://channel6newsonline.com/2011/07/thousands-of-egyptians-protest-against-police-brutality/ |title=Channel 6 News Â» Thousands of Egyptians protest against police brutality |publisher=Channel6newsonline.com |accessdate=2 July 2011}} '''8 July 2011''': The '''"Friday of Determination"'''; Hundreds of thousands of protesters gathered in Suez, Alexandria and Tahrir Square in Cairo. They demanded immediate reforms and swifter prosecution of former officials from the ousted government.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/15899/Egypt/Politics-/Hundreds-of-thousands-revitalise-Egypts-revolution.aspx |title=Hundreds of thousands revitalise Egypt's revolution on Determination Friday â Politics â Egypt â Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |accessdate=10 July 2011}} '''15 July 2011"': Hundreds of thousands continue to protest in Tahrir Square. '''23 July 2011''': Thousands of protesters try to march to the Defense Ministry. They are met with thugs that have sticks, stones, cocktails and other things. The protests are set off by a speech commemorating the 1952 coup led by Mohammed Tantawi. '''1 August 2011''': Egyptian soldiers clash with protesters, tearing down tents. Over 66 people were arrested. Most Egyptians supported the military's action. '''6 August 2011''' Hundreds of protesters gathered and prayed in Tahrir Square. After they were done, they were attacked by the military. '''9 September 2011''': The'''"Friday of Correcting the Path"'''; Tens of thousands of people protested Suez, Alexandria, Cairo, and other cites. Islamist protesters were absent. ===Cities and regions : Mass civil disobedience=== {{Cleanup|section|date=April 2011}} [[File:Flickr - Moe- - IMG 0262.jpg|thumb|Protesters in Alexandria]] [[File:Egy sag.png|thumb|Protesters remove portraits of Ex-president Mubarak in [[Sohag]] City in upper Egypt]] ; Cairo Cairo has been at the epicentre of much of the crisis. The largest protests were held in downtown Tahrir Square, which was considered the "protest movementâs beating heart and most effective symbol."{{cite web|author=Al Jazeera online producer |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/02/20112811181499676.html |title=The different shades of Tahrir â Anger in Egypt |publisher=Al Jazeera English |accessdate=9 February 2011}} On the first three days of the protests, there were clashes between the central security police and protesters and on 28 January, police forces withdrew from all of Cairo. Citizens formed neighbourhood watch groups to keep the order as widespread looting was reported. Traffic police were reintroduced to Cairo on the morning of 31 January.{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/31/AR2011013102845.html|title=Egypt Unrest and Protests Continue as Police Return to Cairo Streets|work=The Washington Post |accessdate=1 February 2011|date=31 January 2011}} An estimated 2 million people protested at Tahrir square. ; Alexandria [[Alexandria]], the home of [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Saeed]], had major protests and clashes with the police. A demonstration on 3 February was reported to include 750,000 people.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} There were few confrontations as not many Mubarak supporters were around, except in occasional motorised convoys escorted by police. The breakdown of law and order, including the general absence of police on the streets, continued through to at least the evening of 3 February, including the looting and burning of one the country's largest shopping centres, Carrefour{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} Alexandria protests were notable for the presence of Christians and Muslims jointly taking part in the events following the [[2011 Alexandria bombing|church bombing]] on 1 January, which saw street protests denouncing Mubarak's regime following the attack. ; Mansoura In the northern city of [[Mansoura, Egypt|Mansoura]] there were protests against the Mubarak regime every day from 25 January onwards. On 27 January, Mansoura was dubbed a "War Zone". On 28 January, 13 were reported dead in violent clashes. On 9 February, 18 more protesters had died. One protest on 1 February was estimated at one million people, The remote city of [[Siwa Oasis|Siwa]] had been relatively calm.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/03/egypt.protests.anxiety/|title=Across dusty Egypt, anxiety has filled the air|last=Sterling|first=Joe|date=4 February 2011|publisher=CNN|accessdate=5 February 2011}} Local [[sheikhs]], who were reportedly in control of the community, put the community under [[lockdown]] after a nearby town was "[[Arson|torched]]."{{cite news|url=http://www.stalbansreview.co.uk/news/8823127.Family__cut_off__amid_Egypt_riots/|title=Mother from St. Albans Speaks to the Review from Egypt|last=Mistry|first=Manisha|work=[[St. Albans Review]] (part of [[Newsquest]])|date=31 January 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}} ; Suez The city of [[Suez]] has seen violent protests. Eyewitness reports have suggested that the death toll there may be high, although confirmation has been difficult due to a ban on media coverage in the area.{{cite web|last=Tencer|first=Daniel|url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2011/01/reports-massacre-suez-protests-egypt/|title=Reports of 'Massacre' in Suez as Protests in Egypt Move into Third day|work=[[The Raw Story]]|date=14 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}} Some online activists referred to Suez as Egypt's [[Sidi Bouzid]], the Tunisian city where protests started.{{Cite news|last=Dziadosz|first=Alexander|title=Could Suez be Egypt's Sidi Bouzid?|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70Q1KZ20110127|accessdate=29 January 2011|agency=Reuters |date=27 January 2011}} A labour strike was held on 8 February.{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09egypt.html?_r=1&pagewanted=2 |title=As Egypt Protest Swells, U.S. Sends Specific Demands |work=The New York Times |accessdate=10 February 2011 |first=David D. |last=Kirkpatrick |date=8 February 2011 }} Large protests took place on 11 February.{{cite news|last = Schemm|first = Paul|last2 = Michael|first2 = Maggie|agency=Associated Press|date=5 February 2011|url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/feb/11/mubarak-leaves-cairo-for-sinai-as-protests-spread/|title = Mubarak leaves Cairo for Sinai as protests spread|publisher=SignOnSanDiego.com|accessdate=12 February 2011 }} On 3 February, 4,000 protesters went to the streets to call for Mubarak's departure.{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/tunisiaNews/idAFLDE71014Z20110203?pageNumber=3&virtualBrandChannel=0 |title=TIMELINE-Protests in Egypt | News by Country | Reuters |publisher=Af.reuters.com |date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=13 April 2011}} ; Tanta Tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets from the first day (25 January) and most of the days after until 11 February. Crowds exceeded a hundred thousand many times. Some hospitals reported casualties during the clashes of 28 January.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} ; Beni Suef [[Beni Suef]] had repeated protests in front of the City Hall on el Kourneish, in front of the Omar abd el Aziz Mosque, and in El Zerayeen Square, on most days during the revolutionary period. Twelve protesters were killed when police opened fire at mass groups protesting in front of the Police Station in Beba, South Beni suef. Many others got injured. Thugs and outlaws have robbed governmental garages and burned down several Government buildings.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} ; Luxor There were also protests in [[Luxor]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/travel-and-living-abroad/travel-advice-by-country/middle-east-north-africa/egypt/ |title=Egypt Travel Advice |publisher=Fco.gov.uk |accessdate=2 February 2011}} ; Dairut Police opened fire on protesters in [[Dairut]] on 11 February. ; Shebin el-Kom Tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets of [[Shebin el-Kom]] on 11 February. ; El-Arish Thousands protested in the city of [[El-Arish]], in the Sinai Peninsula, on 11 February. ; Sohag Large protests took place in the southern city of [[Sohag]] on 11 February. ; Minya Large protests took place in the southern city of [[Minya, Egypt|Minya]] on 11 February. ; Ismailia Nearly 100,000 people protested in and about the local government headquarters in [[IsmaÃ¯lia]] on 11 February. ; Kafr El Sheikh Large protests took place on 28 January and 4 February all over [[Kafr el-Sheikh]].{{citation needed|date=February 2011}} ; Zagazig Over 100,000 protesters gathered on 27 January in front of the city council in [[Zagazig]].http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hmhCDc0LK68 ; Sinai Peninsula [[Bedouins]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]] fought security forces for several weeks.{{cite news|journal=New York Times|title=Protests Swell in Rejection of Egypt"s Limited Reforms|date=8 February 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09egypt.html?pagewanted=2|accessdate=8 February 2011|first=David D.|last=Kirkpatrick}} As a result of the decrease in military forces on the borders, Bedouin groups protected the borders and pledged their support to the ongoing revolution.{{cite web|url=http://www.arabawy.org/2011/02/16/bedouins/ |title=Sinai Bedouins support the #Jan25 Revolution Ø¨Ø¯Ù Ø³ÙÙØ§Ø¡ ÙØ¹ÙÙÙÙ ØªØ£ÙÙØ¯ÙÙ ÙÙØ«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙÙØµØ±ÙØ© " 3arabawy |publisher=Arabawy.org |accessdate=13 April 2011}} *Sharm-El-Sheikh *No protests or civil unrest took place in [[Sharm-El-Sheikh]] on 31 January.{{cite news|author=Stevenson, Rachel|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/31/egypt-sharm-el-sheikh-tourists-tension|title=Sharm El-Sheikh's Tourists Talking About a Revolution|work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=1 February 2011|date=31 January 2011}} All was still calm as Hosni Mubarak and his family left on 11 February. {{-}} ==Deaths== [[File:Martyrs memorial in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|A memorial in Tahrir Square made by the demonstrators in honour of those who died during the protests, regarded as ''[[Shahid|shuhada']]'' Ø´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡ â "martyrs" â in Egyptian parlance. The captions in the pictures attribute most of the deaths to police violence.]] [[File:Sally Zahran.jpg|thumb|Sally Zahran, a female protester who was a victim during demonstrations. [[NASA]] announced plans to write her name on a rocket, as part of a tradition of the American space organization's Jet Propulsion Laboratory to engrave the names of notable people on spacecraft at the request of NASA staff members or US citizens. "This is the least we could do for Egypt's youth and the revolutionaries. This step represents the transfer of the dreams of Egyptian young people from a small stretch of earth to the enormous expanse of space" said NASA researcher Essam Mohamed Haji.{{cite web | url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/314995 | publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm | title=NASA to honor Tahrir Square martyr by putting name on spacecraft | date=10 February 2011 | accessdate=18 April 2011 | author=Zalat, Ali}}]] Leading up to the protests, six cases of [[self-immolation]] were reported, including a man arrested while trying to set himself on fire in downtown Cairo.{{cite web|author=Rosenberg, David|url=http://www.themedialine.org/news/news_detail.asp?NewsID=31194|title=Self-Immolation Spreads Across the Mideast, Inspiring Protest, Controversy|work=[[The Media Line]]|date=24 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}} These cases were inspired by, and began exactly one month after, the acts of self-immolation in Tunisia triggering the [[2010â2011 Tunisian uprising]]. The self-immolated included Abdou Abdel-Moneim Jaafar,{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/7F5D64C8-241F-4F34-B36A-4F259CBF3371.htm?GoogleStatID=20|title=ÙØµØ±Ù ÙØ­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙØ¨Ø±ÙÙØ§Ù|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=17 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}} Mohammed Farouk Hassan,{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE70H3L720110118|title=Egyptians Set Themselves Ablaze After Tunisia Unrest|author=Zayed, Dina|date=18 January 2011|agency=Reuters |accessdate=25 January 2011}} Mohammed Ashour Sorour,{{cite web|url=http://www.elosboaonline.com/show.asp?id=20522&vnum=fesal&page=mahalyat|title=ÙÙØ¸Ù Ø¨Ù'ÙØµØ± ÙÙØ·ÙØ±Ø§Ù' ÙÙØ¯Ø¯ Ø¨Ø­Ø±Ù ÙÙØ³Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù ÙÙØ§Ø¨Ø© Ø§ÙØµØ­ÙÙÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|date=18 January 2011|work=[[El-Aosboa]] (newspaper)|accessdate=25 January 2011}} and Ahmed Hashim al-Sayyed who later died from his injuries.{{cite web | url=http://news.yahoo.com/nphotos/slideshow/photo//110118/ids_photos_wl/r3428700330.jpg/ | archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w6N48d3H | archivedate=29 January 2011 | title=Mother of Ahmed Hashim al-Sayyed | author=[[Staff writer]] | date=18 January 2011 | work=[[Reuters]] (via ''[[Yahoo! News]]'') | accessdate=2 February 2011 }} {{2011 Egyptian protests Death Toll}} As of 30 January, ''Al Jazeera'' reported as many as 150 deaths in the protests.{{Cite news|last=Tomasevic|first=Goran|title=Curfew Hours Extended in Egypt as Turmoil Continues|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20110130/162383449.html|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=30 January 2011}} ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' reported that the dead could include at least 10 policemen, 3 of whom were killed in [[Rafah]] by "an enraged mob".{{cite news|author=Parker, Nick|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/3378537/Troops-battle-rioters-in-Egypt.html?OTC-RSS&ATTR=News|title=Troops Battle Rioters in Egypt|work=The Sun |location=UK |date=29 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}} By 29 January, 2,000 people were known to be injured.{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70S0LX20110129|title=Update 1-Death Toll in Egypt's Protests Tops 100 â Sources |agency=Reuters |date=29 January 2009|accessdate=5 February 2011}} The same day, an employee of the [[Azerbaijan]]i embassy in Egypt was killed while returning home from work in Cairo;{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/azerbaijani-embassy-worker-shot-dead-in-egypt-ministry-says.html|title=Azerbaijani Embassy Worker Shot Dead in Egypt, Ministry Says|author=Agayev, Zulfugar|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}} the next day Azerbaijan sent a plane to evacuate citizens{{cite web|url=http://en.trend.az/news/politics/1820813.html |title=Ambassador: Embassy will continue providing necessary help to Azerbaijanis in Egypt |publisher=En.trend.az |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=5 February 2011}} and opened a criminal investigation into the death.{{cite web|url=http://en.trend.az/news/society/1821118.html|title=Prosecutor General's Office Files Lawsuit on Murder of Accountant of Azerbaijani Embassy in Egypt|date=31 January 2011}} Funerals for the dead on the "Friday of Anger" were held on 30 January. Hundreds of mourners gathered for the funerals calling for Mubarak's removal.{{cite web|author=Nolan, Dan|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/01/2011129171519806580.html|title=Hundreds Mourn the Dead in Egypt|publisher=Al Jazeera English|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}} By 1 February, the protests had left at least 125 people dead,{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8293442/Egypt-crisis-country-braced-for-march-of-a-million.html|title=Egypt Crisis: Country Braced for 'March of a Million' |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |date=31 January 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011 }} although Human Rights Watch said that UN High Commissioner for Human Rights [[Navi Pillay]] claimed that as many as 300 people may have died in the unrest. This unconfirmed tally included 80 Human Rights Watch-verified deaths at two Cairo hospitals, 36 in Alexandria, and 13 in the port city of Suez, among others;{{cite news|author=Carol J. Williams |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/02/egypt-rights-advocates-report-protest-death-toll-as-high-as-300.html |title=Egypt: Rights Advocates Report Protest Death Toll as High as 300 |work=Los Angeles Times|date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8060066-egypt-unrest-claimed-about-300-lives-un-high-commissioner-for-human-rights-navi-pillay|title=Egypt Unrest Claimed About 300 Lives â UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Navi Pillay|publisher=Allvoices.com|accessdate=1 February 2011}}{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/un-human-rights-chief-300-reported-dead-in-egypt-protests-1.340583?localLinksEnabled=false|title=UN Human Rights Chief: 300 Reported Dead in Egypt Protests|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}} over 3,000 people were also reported as injured. An Egyptian Governmental Fact-Finding mission Known as " Fact-Finding National commission About 25 Jan Revolution" announced on 19 April that at least 846 Egyptians died in the nearly three week long popular uprising.{{cite web|url=http://www.ffnc-eg.org/assets/ffnc-eg_final.pdf|title=Fact-Finding National Commission About Jan 25th Revolution Final Report |date=19 April 2011 |accessdate=19 April 2011}}{{cite news|author=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://hosted2.ap.org/APDEFAULT/*/Article_2011-04-19-ML-Egypt/id-ccead68d1b1749dc9bae6d30db014c6|title=Egypt: At least 846 killed in protests |agency=Associated Press |date=19 April 2011 |accessdate=19 April 2011}}{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/406169|title=At least 846 killed in Egyptâs revolution |work=[[Al-Masry Al-Youm]]|date=19 April 2011 |accessdate=19 April 2011}} ==International reactions== {{Main|International reactions to the 2011 Egyptian revolution}} International reactions have varied with most Western states saying peaceful protests should continue but also expressing concern for the stability of the country and the region. The European Union's Foreign Affairs Chief issued a statement saying "I also reiterate my call upon the Egyptian authorities to urgently establish a constructive and peaceful way to respond to the legitimate aspirations of Egyptian citizens for democratic and socioeconomic reforms."{{cite news|last=Ashton|first=Catherine|title=Factbox: International Reaction to Egyptian Protests|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/us-egypt-world-idUSTRE70S2B920110129?pageNumber=2|accessdate=9 April 2011|agency=Reuters |date=29 January 2011}} The United States, Britain, France, Germany and others issued similar statements calling for reforms and an end to violence against peaceful protesters. Many states in the region expressed concern and supported Mubarak, in particular Saudi Arabia, which issued a statement saying it "strongly condemned" the protests,{{cite news|last=CNN Wire Staff|title=Egypt Protests Draw Mixed Reaction in Region|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-01-29/world/egypt.middle.east.reaction_1_egyptian-people-egyptian-president-hosni-mubarak-populous-arab-nation?_s=PM:WORLD|accessdate=9 April 2011|date=15 February 2011}} while others, like Tunisia and Iran, supported the protests. Israel was most cautious for a change, with [[Prime Minister of Israel|Israeli Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] asking his government ministers to maintain silence, and urging Israel's US and European allies to curb their criticism of President Mubarak;{{cite news|title=Israel's Big Fears over a Post-Mubarak Egypt|url=http://www.euronews.net/2011/01/31/israels-big-fears-over-a-post-mubarak-egypt/|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[Euronews]]|date=31 January 2011}}{{cite news|title=Israel Urges World To Curb Criticism of Egypt's Mubarak|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/israel-urges-world-to-curb-criticism-of-egypt-s-mubarak-1.340238|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=31 January 2011}} however, an [[Arab-Israeli]] parliamentarian supported the protests. There were also numerous solidarity protests for the anti-government protesters around the world. NGOs also expressed concern about the protests and the ensuing heavy-handed state response. Amnesty International described attempts to discourage protests as "unacceptable".{{cite web|last=Trimel|first=Suzanne|title=Amnesty International Rebukes Egyptian Leaders for "Failed" Response to Protest Demands Organization Says Leadersâ Efforts to Discourage Protests are "Unacceptable"|url=http://www.amnestyusa.org/document.php?id=ENGUSA20110211001&lang=e&rss=recentnews|accessdate=9 April 2011}} Many countries also issued travel warnings or began evacuating their citizens, including the US, Israel, Great Britain, and Japan. Even [[multinational corporation]]s began evacuating their [[expatriate]] workers.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/30/egypt.evacuations/|title=Foreign governments, businesses begin evacuations from Egypt|publisher=CNN|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}} Many university students were also evacuated. ===Post-ousting=== Many nations, leaders, and organizations hailed the end of the Mubarak regime. There were celebrations in Tunisia, and Lebanon.
