World leaders including Angela Merkel, David Cameron joined in praising the Revolution.{{cite web|last=Baird-Remba|first=Rebecca|title=Mubarak Steps Down: Reactions From Around the World.|url=http://www.allmediany.com/details_news_article.php?news_artid=658|accessdate=9 April 2011}} United States President Barack Obama praised the achievement of the Egyptian people and encouraged other activists by saying "let's look at Egypt's example"{{cite web|last=Obama|first=Barack|title=Follow Egypt's Example, Obama Tells Mideast.|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/02/15/137779.html|accessdate=9 April 2011}} Amid the growing concerns for the country, on 21 February, [[David Cameron]], Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, became the first world leader to visit Egypt since Mubarak was ousted as the president 10 days previously. A news blackout was lifted as the prime minister landed in Cairo for a brief five-hour stopover hastily added at the start of a planned tour of the Middle East.{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2011/feb/21/david-cameron-visits-egypt?CMP=twt_fd |title=David Cameron visits Egypt â The Guardian |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=21 February 2011 |first=Nicholas |last=Watt |date=21 February 2011}} On 15 March United States Secretary of State Hillary Clinton visited Egypt, she was the highest ranking US official to visit Egypt after the handover of power from Mubarak to the military. Clinton urged the military leaders to begin the process of a democratic transition and offer support to those who had been protesting, as well as reaffirming ties between the two nations.{{cite web|last=Thomson|title=Hillary Clinton Egypt Trip Marks Highest Level Visit Since Mubarak's Ouster|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/15/hillary-clinton-egypt-arrives_n_835897.html|accessdate=9 April 2011}} ==Results== {{main|Domestic responses to the Egyptian Revolution of 2011}} [[File:MubarakBurnsEgypt.jpg|thumb|"Nero burned Rome; Mubarak is burning Egypt"]] On 29 January, Mubarak indicated he would be changing the government because despite a "point of no return" being crossed, national stability and [[law and order (politics)|law and order]] must prevail, that he had requested the government, formed only months ago, to step down, and that a new government would be formed.Breaking News. ''[[Al Jazeera English]]''. 29 November 1:30 Egypt time{{Full|February 2011}}{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41318467/|title=Protesters Return to Cairo's Main Square â Egyptian President Fires His Cabinet But Refuses To Step Down|work=[[MSNBC]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}} He then appointed [[Omar Suleiman]], head of Egyptian Intelligence, as vice president and [[Ahmed Shafik]] as prime minister.{{cite news|last=Slackman|first=Michael|title=Choice of Suleiman Likely to Please the Military, Not the Crowds|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/30/world/middleeast/30suleiman.html?src=twrhp|accessdate=3 February 2011|work=The New York Times|date=29 January 2011}} On 1 February, he spoke again saying he would stay in office until [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|the next election in September 2011]] and then leave without standing as a candidate. He also promised to make political reforms. He made no offer to step down. On 31 January, Mubarak swore in his new cabinet in the hope that the unrest would fade. The protesters did not leave and continued to demonstrate in Cairo's [[Tahrir Square]] to demand the downfall of Mubarak. The vice-president and the prime minister were already appointed.{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011131132324475241.html |title=Mubarak Swears in New Cabinet â Egypt's President Appoints New Cabinet in an Attempt To Quell Ongoing Mass Street Protests Against His Rule |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}} He told the new government to preserve subsidies, control inflation and provide more jobs.{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201113101237787481.html |title=Mubarak Orders State Subsidies â Hosni Mubarak Ordered His New PM To Preserve Subsidies, Control Inflation and Provide More Jobs|publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}} On 1 February, Mubarak said he never intended to run for reelection{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121191413252982.html |title=Defiant Mubarak Vows To Finish Term â Violence Erupts in Alexandria Shortly After Egyptian President's Announcement That He Will Not Seek Another Term|publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}} in the [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|upcoming September presidential election]], though his candidacy had previously been announced by high-ranking members of his National Democratic Party{{cite web|author=El-Ghatrify, Alaa|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/211975 |title=NDP Official: President To Run for 6th Term; Gamal Mubarak Candidacy 'Delusory' |work=[[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=21 October 2010|accessdate=4 February 2011}} In his speech, he asked parliament for reforms: {{Bquote|According to my constitutional powers, I call on parliament in both its houses to discuss amending article 76 and 77 of the constitution concerning the conditions on running for presidency of the republic and it sets specific a period for the presidential term. In order for the current parliament in both houses to be able to discuss these constitutional amendments and the legislative amendments linked to it for laws that complement the constitution and to ensure the participation of all the political forces in these discussions, I demand parliament to adhere to the word of the judiciary and its verdicts concerning the latest cases which have been legally challenged.|x|x|Hosni Mubarak|1 February 2011{{cite news|author=[[Transcript (law)|Transcript]]|title=Hosni Mubarak's Speech: Full Text â Egypt President Delivers TV Address to the Nation â and Pledges To Step Down at the Next Election and Pave Way for New Leader|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/02/president-hosni-mubarak-egypt-speech|work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=2 February 2011|accessdate=2 February 2011}}}} Various opposition groups,{{Clarify|date=February 2011}} including the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] (MB), reiterated demands for Mubarak's resignation. The MB also said, after protests turned violent, that it was time for the military to intervene.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698| title=Live: Egypt Unrest|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=28 January 2011|work=BBC News |archivedate=29 January 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w5dpTRTE|quote="Mubarak must step down. It is time for the military to intervene and save the country"}} [[Mohammed ElBaradei]], who said he was ready to lead a transitional government,{{cite web|last=Memmott|first=Mark|url=http://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2011/01/27/133275390/el-baradei-back-in-egypt-says-its-time-for-a-new-government|title=ElBaradei Back In Egypt; Says It's Time For A New Government: The Two-Way|work=[[NPR]]|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}} was also the consensus candidate by a unified opposition including: the ''[[6 April Youth Movement]]'', ''We Are All Khaled Said Movement'', ''[[National Association for Change]]'', ''25 January Movement'', ''[[Kefaya]]'' and the ''Muslim Brotherhood''.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/arabic/middleeast/2011/01/110130_egypt_demo_new.shtml|title=Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ´ ÙØ¯ÙØ¹ Ø¨ØªØ¹Ø²ÙØ²Ø§Øª Ø§Ø¶Ø§ÙÙØ© ÙØ·Ø§Ø¦Ø±Ø§Øª Ø­Ø±Ø¨ÙØ© ØªØ­ÙÙ ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØªØ¸Ø§ÙØ±ÙÙ ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØ§ÙØ±Ø©|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|work=[[BBC Arabic]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}} ElBaradei formed a "steering committee".{{Cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/A5D9789E-24E2-4A8F-B8E5-CC585AF34A23.htm|title=ÙØ¬ÙØ© ÙØ·ÙÙØ© ÙÙÙØ§ÙØ¶Ø© ÙØ¸Ø§Ù ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}} On 5 February, a "national dialogue" was started between the government and opposition groups to work out a transitional period before democratic elections. Many of [[Al-Azhar Mosque|Al-Azhar Imams]] joined the protesters on 30 January all over the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.elaph.com/Web/arts/2011/1/628400.html|title=Ø®Ø§ÙØ¯ Ø§ÙØµØ§ÙÙ ÙÙÙØ¯ ÙØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø© ÙÙ ÙÙØ¯Ø§Ù Ø§ÙØªØ­Ø±ÙØ±|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|date=30 January 2011|work=[[Elaph]]|accessdate=30 January 2011}} Christian leaders asked their congregations to stay away from protests, though a number of young Christian activists joined the protests led by Wafd Party member [[Raymond Lakah]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/1049E146-447D-45F9-800E-7F2A064112E1.htm?GoogleStatID=9|title=Ø§ÙÙÙÙØ³Ø© Ø¨ÙÙØ£Ù Ø¹Ù ÙØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª ÙØµØ±|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|date=27 January 2011|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=29 January 2011}} The Muslim Brotherhood joined the revolution on 30 January, calling on all opposition groups to unite against Mubarak, and for the military to intervene. They joined other opposition groups in electing Mohammed el Baradei to lead a National Salvation Government in the interim period.{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/jan/30/egypt-protests-live-updates#block-33|title=Egypt protests â as they happened |location=London |work=The Guardian |first1=Matthew|last1=Weaver|first2=Owen|last2=Bowcott|date=30 January 2011}} The Egyptian state cracked down on the media, and shut down internet access,{{cite web |last=Cowie |first=James |date=27 January 2011 |url=http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/01/egypt-leaves-the-internet.shtml |title=Egypt Leaves the Internet |publisher=[[Renesys]] |accessdate=4 February 2011 }} a primary means of communication for the opposition. Journalists were also harassed by the regime's supporters, eliciting condemnation from the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]], European countries and the United States. ===Reform process=== {{see also|Egyptian constitutional review committee of 2011}} The protests initiated a process of social and political reform by articulating a series of demands. Reform began with President Mubarak's announcements that concessions would be made towards reform and was highlighted by his resignation 18 days after the protests started. The list of demands for broader changes in Egyptian society and governance, articulated by protesters and activists, includes the following: [[File:A sign with with the protests demand.jpg|thumb|upright|A sign with the protesters' omnibus demands]] [[File:Shreaded paper in Egypt's SS HQ.jpg|thumb|upright|Shredded documents found inside State Security Investigations Service]] {| class="wikitable" |+ Demands of the protestors{{cite web |url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/02/10/egypt-a-list-of-demands-from-tahrir-square/ |title=Egypt: A List of Demands from Tahrir Square |publisher=Global Voices |date=10 February 2011 }} ! style="width:70%;"| Demand ! style="width:15%;"| Status ! style="width:15%;"| Date |- | 1. Resignation of President [[Mohammed Hosni Mubarak]]. | Met. | 11 February 2011 |- | 2. Canceling the [[State of Emergency#Egypt|State of Emergency]] (colloquially referred to as "[[Emergency law in Egypt|The Emergency Law]]"). | Not Met.{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/11/world/middleeast/11egypt-military-statement.html| author=The New York Times |title=Statement From the Supreme Council of the Egyptian Armed Forces. |date=11 February 2011, |accessdate=11 February 2011}} | TBA |- | 3. Dismantling the [[State Security Investigations Service]]. | Claims to be met.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12751234 Egypt dissolves notorious internal security agenc], ''[[BBC News]]'', 15 March 2011 | 15 March 2011 |- | 4. Announcement by (Vice-President) [[Omar Suleiman]] that he will not run in the next presidential elections. | Met.{{cite news |url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFWEA576620110203/ |title=Egypt's Suleiman says will not run for president |publisher=Reuters Africa |date=3 February 2011 }} | 3 February 2011 |- | 5. Dissolving the [[Parliament of Egypt|Parliament]]. | Met. | 13 February 2011 |- | 6. Release of all prisoners taken since 25 January. | Ongoing | 20 February 2011 |- | 7. Ending of the recently imposed curfew. | Met.[http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/06/201161563513344977.html], ''[Al Jazeera News]", 15 June 2011 | 15 June 2011 |- | 8. Removing the [[State Security Intelligence|SSI]]-controlled university-police. | Claims to be met. | 3 March 2011 |- | 9. Reimbursing shop owners for losses during the curfew | Announced but Not Met. | 7 February 2011 |- | 12. Dissolving the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]]. | Claims to be met. | 16 April 2011 |- | 14. Arrest, Interrogation and Trial of (now-former) president [[Hosni Mubarak]] and his two sons: [[Gamal Mubarak]] and [[Alaa Mubarak]]. | Met; All ordered to stand trial. | 24 May 2011 |} [[File:Referendum in the desert.jpg|275px|thumb|The voters' line in [[Mokattam]], Cairo, during the [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|constitutional referendum]] on 19 March 2011. The queue was so long it extended well outside the built-up area of Mokattam and into the desert. The referendum witnessed an unprecedented turnout of voters, with over 18 million Egyptians casting their votes.]] On 17 February, an Egyptian prosecutor ordered the detention of three ex-ministers, former Interior Minister Habib el-Adli, former Tourism Minister Zuhair Garana and former Housing Minister Ahmed el-Maghrabi, and a prominent businessman, steel magnate Ahmed Ezz, pending trial on suspicion of wasting public funds. The public prosecutor also froze the accounts of Adli and his family members on accusations that over 4 million Egyptian pounds ($680,000) were transferred to his personal account by a head of a contractor company, while calling on the Foreign Minister to contact European countries and ask them to freeze the accounts of the defendants.{{cite news |title=Egypt detains ex-ministers |author=[[Al-Jazeera English]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011217221111216445.html |date=17 February 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2011}} Meanwhile, the United States announced on the same day that it was giving Egypt $150 million in crucial economic assistance to help it transition towards democracy following the overthrow of long time president Mubarak. US Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] said that [[William Joseph Burns|William Burns]], the Under-secretary of State for political affairs, and [[David Lipton]], a senior White House adviser on international economics, would travel to Egypt the following week. On 19 February, a moderate Islamic party, named ({{Lang-ar|Ø­Ø²Ø¨ Ø§ÙÙØ³Ø· Ø§ÙØ¬Ø¯ÙØ¯}}) [[Al-Wasat Party|Al-Wasat Al-Jadid]], or the '''New Center Party''', which was outlawed for 15 years was granted official recognition by an Egyptian court. The party was founded in 1996 by activists who split off from the Muslim Brotherhood and sought to create a tolerant Islamic movement with liberal tendencies, but its attempts to register as an official party were rejected four times since then. On the same day, Prime Minister Ahmed Shafiq said 222 political prisoners would be released. He said only a few were detained during the popular uprising and put the number of remaining political prisoners at 487, but did not say when they would be released.{{cite news |title=Egypt recognizes moderate Islamic party, promises to release political prisoners |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/egypt-recognizes-moderate-islamic-party-promises-to-release-political-prisoners/article1914290/ |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=20 February 2011 |location=Toronto |work=Globe and Mail |location=Canada }} On 20 February, Dr. {{link-interwiki|en=Yehia El Gamal|lang=ar|lang_title=ÙØ­ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¬ÙÙ}} a well known activist and law professor, announced (on TV channels) accepting a Vice Prime Minister position within the new government that will be announced on 21â22 February. He also announced the removal of many of the previous government members to alleviate the situation. On 21 February, the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] announced it would form a political party for the upcoming parliamentary election, called the [[Freedom and Justice Party (Egypt)|Freedom and Justice Party]], which was to be led by Dr. Saad Ketatni.{{cite web | url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/325599 | title=Muslim Brotherhood to establish 'Freedom and Justice Party' | publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm }}{{cite web | url=http://www.ikhwanweb.com/article.php?id=28088 | title=The Muslim Brotherhood Official English Website | publisher=Ikhwanweb | date=23 February 2011 | accessdate=5 March 2011 }}{{cite web | last=Gordon | first=Evelyn | url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=209563&R=R3 | title=Muslim Brotherhood sits at Egyptâs new democratic table |work=Jerusalem Post | date=23 February 2011 | accessdate=5 March 2011 }} Its spokesperson noted that "when we talk about the slogans of the revolution â freedom, social justice, equality â all of these are in the [[Sharia]] (Islamic law)."{{cite web | url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/02/23/138826.html | title=Muslim Brothers see corruption-free Egypt flourishing | publisher=Alarabiya.net | date=23 February 2011 | accessdate=5 March 2011 }} On 3 March, Prime Minister Shafik submitted his resignation to the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces. The Council appointed [[Essam Sharaf]], a former Minister of Transport who began vocal criticism of the regime following his resignation, particularly after the [[Qalyoub rail accident]] in 2006, to replace Shafik and form a new government. Sharaf's appointment is seen as a significant concession to protesters, as he had been actively involved during the action at Tahrir Square.{{cite news|author=[[BBC News]]|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12634117|title=Egypt's Prime Minister Ahmed Shafiq resigns|publisher=BBC |date=3 March 2011|accessdate=3 March 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://fr.euronews.net/depeches/772863-egypte-demission-du-premier-ministre-ahmad-chafic/ |title=Egypte: le Premier ministre remplacÃ©, satisfaction des opposants |work=Euronews |language=French |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=3 March 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/6892/Egypt/Politics-/Meet-Essam-Sharaf-Egypts-first-postrevolution-Prim.aspx |title=Meet Essam Sharaf: Egypt's first post-revolution Prime Minister |work=Ahram Online |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=3 March 2011}} Sharaf appointed former [[International Court of Justice]] judge [[Nabil Elaraby]] as Foreign Minister and General Mansour El Essawi as Interior Minister.{{cite web | url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=211001 | title=Egypt's Elaraby accepts foreign minister post |work=Jerusalem Post | accessdate=7 March 2011 }}{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011365436227288.html | title=Egypt PM appoints new key ministers | publisher=Al Jazeera English | accessdate=7 March 2011 }} On 16 April, the Higher Administrative Court dissolved the former ruling National Democratic Party (NDP) and ordered its funds and property to be handed over to the government.{{cite news |title=Egypt dissolves former ruling party |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/2011416125051889315.html |date=16 April 2011 |accessdate=16 April 2011}} On 24 May 2011, it was announced that Egypt's ousted President Hosni Mubarak and his two sons Gamal and Alaa are to be tried over the deaths of anti-government protesters in the revolution that began on 25 January.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13527102|title=Egypt: Hosni Mubarak and sons to be tried over deaths and should be killed for their crimes.|date=24 May 2011|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=24 May 2011}} ===Court trials of state officials accused of corruption=== {{main|Trials and judicial hearings following the 2011 Egyptian revolution}} The ousting of Mubarak was followed by a series of arrests of, and / or imposed travel bans on high profile figures on charges of causing the death of 300â500 demonstrators, and the injury of 5,000 more, as well as charges of [[embezzlement]], [[Profiteering (business)|profiteering]], [[money laundry]], and [[Human rights abuses|abuse of human rights]]. Among these figures are Mubarak himself, his wife [[Suzanne Mubarak]], his son [[Gamal Mubarak|Gamal]], his son [[Alaa Mubarak|Alaa]], the former Interior Minister [[Habib el-Adly]], the former Housing Minister Ahmed El-Maghrabi, the former Tourism Minister [[Zoheir Garana]] and the former Secretary of the National Democratic Party for Organisational Affairs [[Ahmed Ezz]].{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1036/eg31.htm |title=How the mighty have fallen |publisher=Al-Ahram Weekly |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}} Mubarak's ousting was also followed by widespread allegations of corruption against numerous other government officials and senior politicians{{cite news|first=Phillip |last=Inman |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/04/hosni-mubarak-family-fortune |title=Mubarak family fortune could reach $70bn, say experts |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=4 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289811&IssueID=2068 |title=ÙØµØ·ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙÙÙ: Ø´Ø®ØµÙØ© ÙØ¨ÙØ±Ø© ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ±Ø¦Ø§Ø³Ø© Ø£ÙØ¯Øª ÙÙ Ø£Ù "ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù" ÙÙ ÙØªØ±Ø´Ø­ ÙØ§Ø¨ÙÙ Ø³ÙÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¨Ø¯ÙÙ |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |accessdate=16 March 2011}} On 28 February 2011, Egypt's top prosecutor ordered an asset freeze for Mubarak and his family.{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Egypt-Issues-Travel-Ban-Asset-Freeze-on-Mubarak-117076003.html |title=Egypt Issues Travel Ban, Asset Freeze on Mubarak |publisher=Voice of America |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}} This was followed by arrest warrants, travel bans and judicial orders to freeze the assets of other known public figures, including the former Speaker of the Egyptian Parliament, [[Fathi Sorour]], and the former Speaker of the Higher Legislative Body ([[Shura Council]]), [[Safwat El Sherif]].{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/6644/Egypt/Politics-/NDP-fires-Mubarak--then-what.aspx |title=NDP fires Mubarak â then what? |publisher=Ahram Online |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/news/Egypt/Politics/2011/March/6/elshrief_announcement.aspx |title=Ø§ÙØ´Ø±ÙÙ ÙÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØªÙØ§ÙÙ Ø­Ø³Ø§Ø¨Ø§Øª Ø®Ø§ØµØ© Ø®Ø§Ø±Ø¬ ÙØµØ± |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=6 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}} Arrest warrants were also issued against some public figures who left the country with the outbreak of the revolution. These warrants were issued on allegations of financial misappropriations, rather than human rights abuses. Among these public figures are [[Rachid Mohamed Rachid]], the former Minister of Trade and Industry and [[Hussein Salem]], a business tycoon. Salem is believed to have left for Dubai{{cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000619367&fid=1725 |title=Hussein Salem caught in Dubai with $500m |publisher=Globes |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}} Trials of the accused officials started on 5 March 2011 when the former Interior Minster of Egypt, [[Habib el-Adli]], appeared before the Giza Criminal Court in Cairo.{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/february/27/adly_judgment.aspx |title=5 ÙØ§Ø±Ø³.. Ø¨Ø¯Ø¡ ÙØ­Ø§ÙÙØ© Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¯ÙÙ Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§ÙØ§Øª |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=27 February 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}} The trials of el-Adli and other public figures are expected to run a lengthy course. In March 2011, following the revolution, [[Abbud al-Zumar]], one of Egypt's most famous political prisoners, was freed after 30 years. He was founder and first emir of the [[Egyptian Islamic Jihad]], and implicated in the assassination of President Anwar Sadat on 6 October 1981.{{cite book|last=Atkins|first=Stephen E.|title=The 9/11 EncyclopÃ¦dia|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=PDDIgWRN_HQC&pg=PA456|accessdate=6 May 2011|date=31 May 2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781598849219|pages=456â}} On 24 May, former Egyptian President Mubarak was ordered to stand trial on charges of [[premeditated murder]] of peaceful protestors during the 2011 Egyptian revolution and, if convicted, could face the death penalty. The full list of charges released by the public prosecutor was "intentional murder, attempted killing of some demonstrators...misuse of influence and deliberately wasting public funds and unlawfully making private financial gains and profits." ==Analysis== ===Regional instability=== {{main|Arab Spring}} The Egyptian Revolution, along with the events in Tunisia, have sparked a [[Revolutionary wave|wave of major uprisings]]. [[Demonstration (people)|Demonstrations]] and protests have spread across the [[MENA|Middle East and North Africa]]. To date [[2010â2011 Algerian protests|Algeria]], [[2011 Bahraini protests|Bahrain]], [[2011 Iranian protests|Iran]], [[2011 Jordanian protests|Jordan]], [[2011 Libyan civil war|Libya]], [[2011 Morocco protests|Morocco]],[[2011 Yemeni uprising|Yemen]], and [[2011 Syrian uprising|Syria]] have all witnessed major protests. In addition, minor incidents have occurred in [[2011 Iraqi protests|Iraq]], Kuwait, [[Mauritania]], [[2011 Omani protests|Oman]], [[2011 Saudi Arabian protests|Saudi Arabia]], Somalia, and [[2011 Sudanese protests|Sudan]]. ===Religion and politics=== {{see|Islam and democracy|Secularism in Egypt}} {{see also|Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt|Gama'at Islamiya|Egyptian Islamic Jihad}} {{multiple image | width1 = 156 | width2 = 180 | align = | footer = A Muslim wearing the [[Christian cross|cross]] in solidarity with Christian; and a [[Copt]] Christian (left) and a [[Salafi]] Muslim (right) debate in ''Tahrir Square'' on politics and the revolution | image1 = A Muslim wearing the cross in solidarity with Christians.jpg | image2 = Debating in Tahrir.jpg }} The protests in Egypt were not centred around religion-based politics, but nationalism and a broad-based social consciousness.{{cite web | url=http://palestinenote.com/blogs/blogs/archive/2011/02/28/secularism-is-what-the-arab-world-needs.aspx | title=Secularism is what the Arab world needs â Blog Post | publisher=Palestinenote.com | date=28 February 2011 | accessdate=5 March 2011 }} Before the uprising, the most organised and prominent opposition movements throughout the Arab world usually came from Islamist organisations that relied on a conviction of their faith, where members were motivated and ready to sacrifice. However, secular forces emerged from the revolution touting principles that religious groups shared with them: freedom, social justice, and dignity. Islamist organisations also emerged with greater freedom to operate. Although the cooperative, inter-faith revolution itself was no guarantee that partisan politics would not re-emerge in its wake, its success nonetheless represented a change from the intellectual stagnation created by decades of repression which simply pitted modernity and Islam against one another as conflicting and incompatible. Islamists and secularists both have been faced with new opportunities for dialogue and discourse, on matters such as the role of Islam and Sharia in society and freedom of speech, as well as the impact of secularism on a predominantly Muslim population.{{cite web | url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0304/An-upside-of-Arab-revolts-Islamists-talk-democracy | title=An upside of Arab revolts: Islamists talk democracy | publisher=CSMonitor.com | accessdate=5 March 2011 }} Despite the optimism surrounding the revolution, several commentators have expressed concerns about the risk of increased power and influence for Islamist forces in the country and the region at large, as well as the difficulties of integrating the different groups, ideologies, and visions for the country among the population. Journalist [[Caroline Glick]] argued that the Egyptian revolution portends a rise in religious radicalism and support for terrorism, citing a 2010 [[Pew]] Opinion poll which found that Egyptians support Islamists over modernizers by a ratio of over 2 to 1.{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Columnists/Article.aspx?id=206121|title=Our World: Clueless in Washington|author=Glick, Caroline|accessdate=10 April 2011|publisher=Jerusalem Post}} Journalist [[Shlomo Ben-Ami]] argued that Egypt's most formidable task is to refute the old paradigm of the Arab World that sees the only choices for regimes as between either repressive, secular dictatorships or repressive theocracies. He noted, however that with Islam such a central part of the society, any emergent regime is bound to be attuned to religion. In his view a democracy that excluded all religion from public life, as in France, could succeed in Egypt and no Arab democracy could disallow the participation of political Islam if it were to be genuine.{{cite web|url=http://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/benami51/English7 |title=Saving the Egyptian Revolution |publisher=[[Project Syndicate]] |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}} Since the revolution Islamist parties such as the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] have shown unprecedented strength in the new more democratic landscape, taking leading roles in constitutional changes, voter mobilization, and protests.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/21/world/middleeast/21egypt.htm|title=Egyptian Voters Approve Constitutional Changes|author=MacFarquhar, Neil|accessdate=10 April 2011|work=New York Times|date=20 March 2011}}{{cite news|last=Bradley |first=Matt |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704587004576244922383434098.html |title=Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood to Rejoin Protests |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=13 April 2011}} This was a noted concern among the secular and youth movements, who wanted any elections to be held later rather than sooner, so that they might catch up with the already well-organized groups. Elections are to be held in September 2011 and it is unclear which group or approach will prevail. ===Women's role=== {{multiple image | width1 = 151 | width2 = 170 | align = | footer = A female protester wearing a [[NiqÄb in Egypt|niqÄb]] | image1 = Flickr - Floris Van Cauwelaert - The messages on Tahrir Square (8).jpg }} [[Women in Egypt|Egyptian women]] were active throughout the revolution. Some took part in the protests themselves, were present in news clips and on Facebook forums, and were part of the leadership during the Egyptian revolution. In Tahrir Square, female protesters, some with their children, worked to support the protests. The diversity of the protesters in Tahrir Square was visible in the women who participated; many wore head scarves and other signs of religious conservatism, while others revelled in the freedom to kiss a friend or smoke a cigarette in public. Egyptian women also organised protests, and reported on the events; female bloggers such as Leil Zahra Mortada risked abuse or imprisonment by keeping the world informed of the daily scene in Tahrir Square and elsewhere.{{cite news | last = Wolf | first = Naomi | date=28 February 2011 | url = http://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/wolf33/English | title = The Middle Eastâs Feminist Revolution | publisher=[[Project Syndicate]] | accessdate=1 March 2011 }} Among those who died was [[Sally Zahran]], who was beaten to death during one of the demonstrations. [[NASA]] reportedly plans to name one of its [[Mars]] exploration spacecraft in Zahran's honour.{{cite news | date=12 February 2011 | url = http://www.ndtv.com/article/world/nasa-rocket-to-bear-name-of-egyptian-woman-killed-in-protests-84866 | title = NASA rocket to bear name of Egyptian woman killed in protests | publisher=[[NDTV]] | accessdate=6 March 2011 }} The wide participation and the significant contributions by Egyptian women to the protests have been attributed to the fact that many, especially younger women, are better educated than previous generations, representing more than half of Egyptian university students. This has been an empowering factor for women, who have become more present and active publicly in recent years. The advent of social media has also helped provide tools for women to become protest leaders. ===The military's role=== {{see|Egyptian Armed Forces}} {{multiple image | width1 = 180 | width2 = 180 | align = | footer = From left to right: One of the 2 army vehicles that were burned during the army attacks on 9 April 2011 and one of the protestors holding some of the army bullets, standing in front of a burning army vehicle that was burned during the army attack on 9 April 2011 in Tahrir Square, at least 2 protestors were killed by the army and tens wounded. | image1 = Burning amy vehicle.png | image2 = Tahrir Square attacks on April 9 2011.png }} The [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] enjoy a better reputation with the public than the police does, the former perceived as a professional body protecting the country, the latter accused of [[systemic corruption]] and illegitimate violence. All four [[Egyptian president]]s since the 1950s have come from the military into power. Key Egyptian military personnel include the Defense Minister [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] and General [[Sami Hafez Enan]], Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces.{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110213/D9LC1NLO0.html |title=Key members of Egypt Armed Forces Supreme Council |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |accessdate=13 February 2011}}{{cite news|author=[[Ian Black (journalist)|Black, Ian]]|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-military-hosni-mubarak|title=All Eyes on Egypt's Military as Hosni Mubarak Fortifies Position |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011 }} The Egyptian military totals around 468,500 well-armed active personnel, plus a reserve of 479,000.{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/30/uk-egypt-protests-military-idUKTRE70T29420110130|title=Factbox â Egypt's Powerful Military|agency=Reuters |date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}} As Head of Egypt's Armed Forces, Tantawi has been described as "aged and change-resistant" and is attached to the old regime. He has used his position as Defense Minister to oppose reforms, economic and political, which he saw as weakening central government authority. Other key figures, Sami Enan chief among them, are younger and have closer connections to both the US and groups such as the Muslim Brotherhood. An important aspect of the relationship between the Egyptian and American military establishments is the 1.3 billion dollars in military aid provided to Egypt annually, which in turn pays for American-made military equipment, and allows Egyptian officers to receive training in the US. Guaranteed this aid package, the governing [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|military council]] is for the most reform-resistant.{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/14/wikileaks-cables-egyptian-military-head |title=WikiLeaks cables: Egyptian military head is 'old and resistant to change' |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |first1=Julian |last1=Borger |first2=James |last2=Ball}}{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/cifamerica/2011/feb/04/egypt-arms-trade?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487 |title=Egypt's military-industrial complex |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=4 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |first=Pratap |last=Chatterjee}} One analyst however, while conceding that the military is change-resistant, states it has no option but to facilitate the process of democratisation. Furthermore, the military will have to keep its role in politics limited to continue good relations with the West, and must not restrict the participation of political Islam if there is to be a genuine democracy. ===Foreign relations=== {{main|Foreign relations of Egypt}} Foreign governments in the West including the US have regarded Mubarak as an important ally and [[Foreign relations of Egypt#Israeli-Palestinian conflict|supporter]] in the [[Israeli-Palestinian conflict|Israeli-Palestinian]] peace negotiations. After wars with [[Israel]] in 1948, '56, '67 and '73, Egypt signed a [[EgyptâIsrael Peace Treaty|peace treaty]] in 1979, provoking controversy in the [[Arab world]]. As provisioned in the 1978 [[Camp David Accords]], which led to the peace treaty, both Israel and Egypt receive billions of dollars in aid annually from the United States, with Egypt receiving over US$1.3 billion of military aid each year in addition to economic and development assistance.{{cite web| title = Background Note: Egypt| publisher=[[United States Department of State]]| date=10 November 2010| url = http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5309.htm| accessdate=28 January 2011}} According to Juan Cole, many Egyptian youth feel ignored by Mubarak on the grounds that he is not looking out for their best interests and that he rather serves the interests of the West.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/30/opinion/main20030008.shtml|title=Why Egypt's Class Conflict Is Boiling Over â Juan Cole: How Decades of Economic Stumbles Set the Stage for Egypt's Current Political Turmoil|author=Cole, Juan (essay)|date=30 January 2011|work=[[CBS News]]|accessdate=4 February 2011}} The cooperation of the Egyptian regime in enforcing the [[blockade of the Gaza Strip]] was also deeply unpopular among the general Egyptian public.{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/jan/25/egypt.israelandthepalestinians1 |title=Mubarak under pressure | World news | guardian.co.uk |work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=6 February 2011 |date=25 January 2008}} ===Online activism and the role of social media=== [[File:AlJazeeraEgypt.png|left|thumb|Coverage by the news network [[Al Jazeera English]] provided information about the revolution outside Egypt.]] The April 6 Youth Movement (Arabic: Ø­Ø±ÙØ© Ø´Ø¨Ø§Ø¨ 6 Ø£Ø¨Ø±ÙÙâ) is an Egyptian Facebook group started in Spring 2008 to support the workers in El-Mahalla El-Kubra, an industrial town, who were planning to strike on April 6. Activists called on participants to wear black and stay home on the day of the strike. Bloggers and citizen journalists used Facebook, Twitter, Flickr, blogs and other new media tools to report on the strike, alert their networks about police activity, organize legal protection and draw attention to their efforts. The New York Times has identified the movement as the political Facebook group in Egypt with the most dynamic debates. As of January 2009[update], it had 70,000 predominantly young and educated members, most of whom had not been politically active before; their core concerns include free speech, nepotism in government and the country's stagnant economy. Their discussion forum on Facebook features intense and heated discussions, and is constantly updated with new postings. the founders of the movement * Ahmed Maher was a prominent participant in the anti-Mubarak demonstrations in Egypt in 2011. * Asmaa Mahfouz posted a video blog that went viral. She urged the Egyptian people to join her in a protest on January 25, in Tahrir Square to bring down Mubarakâs regime and urged people not to be afraid. * Waleed Rashed (Arabic ÙÙÙØ¯ Ø±Ø§Ø´Ø¯ ) born November 15, 1983 in El Sharkia, Egypt), is one of the co-founders of the April 6 Youth Movement and a prominent participant in the anti-Mubarak demonstrations in Egypt in 2011. [[We are all Khaled Said|We Are All Khaled Saeed]] is a Facebook group which formed in the aftermath of Saeed's beating and death. The group attracted hundreds of thousands of members worldwide and played a prominent role in spreading and bringing attention to the growing discontent. As the protests began, Google executive [[Wael Ghonim]] revealed that he was the person behind the account.{{cite news|title = Who is Wael Ghonim?|date=8 February 2011|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|url = http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2011/02/08/f-wael-ghonim.html|work=CBC News|accessdate=17 February 2011}} Later after the revolution, in an TV interview in the presence of member of the ruling military council, it was revealed that AbdulRahman Mansour, a young underground activist and media expert shared the account with Wael Ghonim.{{cite news|title = ØªÙØ±ÙØ± Ø®Ø§Øµ- ÙÙ Ø¯Ø§Ø®Ù Ø§ÙØ«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙÙØµØ±ÙØ©|url = http://ara.reuters.com/article/topNews/idARACAE73C0QW20110413?sp=true|date=13 April 2011|agency=Reuters |format = transcript|accessdate=6 February 2011}} Another potent viral online contribution was made by [[Asmaa Mahfouz]], a female activist who posted a video in which she challenged people to publicly protest.{{cite news|title = Women play vital role in Egypt's uprising|url = http://www.npr.org/2011/02/04/133497422/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising|date=4 February 2011|work=National Public Radio|format = transcript|accessdate=6 February 2011}} Previously, Facebook had suspended the group because some of its administrators were using pseudonyms, a violation of the company's 'Terms of Service.'{{cite news|title = Can Egypt's Internet Movement Be Exported?|date=18 February 2011|publisher=[[The Nation]]|url = http://www.thenation.com/print/article/158717/can-egypts-internet-movement-be-exported|work=The Nation|accessdate=23 February 2011}} The usage of [[social media]] has been extensive.{{cite news | url=http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/social-media-cellphone-video-fuel-arab-protests-2227088.html | title=Social media, cellphone video fuel Arab protests |work=The Independent |location=UK | date=27 February 2011 | accessdate=6 March 2011 }}{{cite web | url=http://www.worldpoliticsreview.com/articles/8089/the-realist-prism-politics-vs-social-media-in-the-arab-uprising | title=The Realist Prism: Politics vs. Social Media in the Arab Uprising | publisher=World Politics Review | date=25 January 2011 | accessdate=6 March 2011 }} {{cite web | url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2011/02/17/946150/-History-of-the-Revolution-on-Facebook | title=History of the Revolution on Facebook | publisher=Daily Kos | date=17 Feb. 2011 | accessdate=29 May 2011 }} {{cite web | url=http://techcrunch.com/2011/02/11/feb11/ | title=Mubarak Shut Down The Internet, And The Internet Paid Him In Kind | publisher=TechCrunch | date=11 Feb. 2011 | accessdate=26 June 2011 }} As one Egyptian activist succinctly tweeted during the protests there, "We use Facebook to schedule the protests, Twitter to coordinate, and YouTube to tell the world."{{cite web | url=http://www.miller-mccune.com/politics/the-cascading-effects-of-the-arab-spring-28575/ | title=The Arab Uprising's Cascading Effects | publisher=Miller-McCune | date=23 February 2011 | accessdate=6 March 2011 }} Internet censorship has also been extensive, and in some cases comprehensive to the extent of taking entire nation-states practically off-line.{{cite web | url=http://www.monkey.org/~labovit/blog/ | title=Craig Labovitz's Blog | publisher=Monkey.org | accessdate=6 March 2011 }} It is readily believed that a handful of people through Facebook, Twitter, and blogging sparked this uprising. One of which is [[Wael Ghonim]]. Many believe Ghonim was the first contributor to spark the Egypt revolution when he created a Facebook page dedicated to Khaled Saeed entitled [[We are all Khaled Said|We Are All Khaled Saeed]] . Saeed, an Egyptian business man was beaten to death by police in June 2010. It is believed that this was in retaliation to a video he posted showing Egyptian police sharing the spoils of a drug bust. The Facebook page blew up to over 400,000 followers, creating an online arena where protestors and those discontent with the government could gather, vent, and organise. The page called for protests on 25 January, Known as the day of wrath. Hundreds of thousands of protestors flooded the streets to show their discontent with the murder and the corruption within their country. Ghonim was jailed the 28th and released 12 days later. Ghonim has also gained quite a large following through his Twitter account where he has been creating a narrative of the events happening day to day in Egypt. Ghonim is the Middle East and North African marketing manager at Google. He is currently on leave. Another major contributor is Egyptian activist and member of the 6 April movement Though these two are credited with being the first social media faces of this revolution, since the 25th people have posted videos, tweeted, and wrote Facebook comments to keep the world abreast of the turmoil in Egypt. Including videos posted of a badly beaten Khaled Said, disproving the first claims by the police that he had choked to death. Ali documents the various ways in which social media was used by Egyptian activists, some of the most prominent Egyptian celebrities, and as well by major political figures abroad to invigorate the protests.{{cite journal |first=Amir |last=Ali |url=http://harvardhrj.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/185-220.pdf |title=The Power of Social Media in Developing Nations: New Tools for Closing the Global Digital Divide and Beyond |journal=Harvard Human Rights Journal |volume=24 |issue=1 |pages=185â189, 208â210 }} [[Sharif Abdel Kouddous]], a journalist with [[Democracy Now!]] had provided live coverage and [[Twitter|tweets]] from [[Tahrir Square]] during the protests and has also been credited with using new media to raise awareness regarding the protests.[http://www.democracynow.org/2011/3/30/sharif_abdel_kouddous_transitions_from_democracy][http://pulitzercenter.org/people/sharif-abdel-kouddous] The role of social media in the Egyptian uprising has since been widely written and debated about, including in the first edition of the [[Dubai Debates]] on the question "Mark Zuckerberg â the new hero of the Arab people?" [http://www.dubaidebates.com/debates/view/1/mark-zuckerberg-the-new-hero-of-the-arab-people] Many have argued, based in part on the Egyptian revolution, that social media may be an effective tool in developing nations more generally.{{cite journal |first=Amir |last=Ali |url=http://harvardhrj.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/185-220.pdf |title=The Power of Social Media in Developing Nations: New Tools for Closing the Global Digital Divide and Beyond |journal=Harvard Human Rights Journal |volume=24 |issue=1 |pages=205â208 }} Critics that claim social networking didn't instigate the Arab Spring, argue on five major pointshttp://www.cracked.com/article_19225_5-reasons-twitter-isnt-actually-overthrowing-governments.html: that people in the Middle East generally don't use social networking sites,http://blog.sysomos.com/2009/06/21/a-look-at-twitter-in-iran/{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/jun/09/iran-twitter-revolution-protests |location=London |work=The Guardian | first=Matthew | last=Weaver | title=Iran's 'Twitter revolution' was exaggerated, says editor | date=9 June 2010}} that social networking sites aren't private enough to evade authorities,{{cite news| url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB125978649644673331.html | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=Farnaz | last=Fassihi | title=Iranian Crackdown Goes Global | date=3 December 2009}} that many people don't trust social networking as a source for news,http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/jun2009/tc20090617_803990_page_2.htm that social networking sites were promoted by the media,http://www.rferl.org/content/tunisia_can_we_please_stop_talking_about_twitter_revolutions/2277052.html and finally that social networking sites make non-activists feel involved in the revolutions.http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/04/15/egypt-gene-sharp-taught-us-how-to-revolt/ == After-Revolution Freedom of Establishing Political Parties == Freedom was given to establish political parties only by "notifying" concerned authorities, resulting in establishing several political parties named after or in relation to the 25 January revolution.
